Clinical Pearls

• Attacks often occur 2–4 hours post‐exercise when insulin drives K⁺ intracellularly.
• ECG may show U‐waves, flattened T‐waves; monitor for arrhythmias.
• Prophylaxis: acetazolamide or potassium‐sparing diuretics (e.g., spironolactone).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing as Guillain‐Barré syndrome—GBS has sensory symptoms, areflexia, albuminocytologic dissociation.
2. Overlooking rapid K⁺ measurement—delay can miss the hypokalemia window; normalization of K⁺ between attacks obscures diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EFNS/Peripheral Nerve Society (2015): “Diagnostic criteria and management of primary periodic paralyses” recommend immediate serum K⁺ in suspected HypoPP (Level B).
2. Morrow et al. (Neurology 2010;74:105–112): RCT demonstrating acetazolamide reduces attack frequency and severity in familial HypoPP (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

HypoPP involves the sarcolemma of skeletal muscle fibers: mutations in voltage‐gated Ca²⁺ (CACNA1S) or Na⁺ channels (SCN4A) impair action‐potential initiation when extracellular K⁺ falls.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutant channels allow an anomalous gating pore current. During triggers (exercise, high carbs), insulin promotes K⁺ influx, hyperpolarizes the resting membrane, inactivates Na⁺ channels, and renders muscle fiber inexitable.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize episodic flaccid weakness with preserved sensation and consciousness.
2. Draw serum K⁺ immediately; check ECG.
3. Exclude differential (rhabdo, GBS, myasthenia gravis).
4. Perform long‐exercise EMG test.
5. Confirm with genetic testing for CACNA1S/SCN4A.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute: oral/IV KCl (10–20 mEq), avoid glucose‐containing fluids.
Chronic prophylaxis: acetazolamide 125–250 mg BID or spironolactone 25–50 mg daily.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Episodic muscle weakness with exercise trigger and normal sensation should prompt measurement of serum potassium; HypoPP is tested as a prototypical channelopathy on neurology boards.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Proximal muscle weakness localizes to a myopathy rather than a neuropathy or neuromuscular junction disorder. Key concepts:
• Muscle fiber morphology: variation in fiber size, internal nuclei, necrosis, and fibrosis point toward a primary myopathic process.
• Dystrophinopathies: X-linked disorders causing absence or reduction of dystrophin on the sarcolemma, leading to progressive degeneration of muscle fibers.
• Distinction from NMJ disorders: In conditions like myasthenia gravis or Lambert-Eaton syndrome, muscle histology is typically normal.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene leading to absent sarcolemmal dystrophin. On biopsy one sees:
• Marked variation in fiber size, central nuclei, necrotic/regenerating fibers, and endomysial fibrosis.
• Absent immunohistochemical staining for dystrophin.
Clinical guidelines (AAN 2018) recommend genetic testing for DMD mutations as first-line, with muscle biopsy reserved when genetic results are inconclusive (Level B evidence). Recent studies (Sunada et al., 2021) confirm that absent dystrophin correlates with early onset proximal weakness and elevated CK levels >10× normal. The absence of statin exposure excludes drug-induced necrotizing myopathy, reinforcing a genetic dystrophinopathy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Antimicrotubule-associated myopathy
• Why incorrect: Microtubule‐targeting agents (e.g., vincristine) predominantly cause peripheral neuropathy, not primary myopathy.
• Misconception: Confusing neurotoxic vs myotoxic chemotherapy effects.
• Differentiator: Biopsy in microtubule toxicity shows neurogenic atrophy, not fiber necrosis and fibrosis.

B. Myasthenia gravis
• Why incorrect: An autoimmune postsynaptic NMJ disorder; muscle histology is normal aside from type grouping on EMG.
• Misconception: Equating fatigable weakness with structural muscle damage.
• Differentiator: Edrophonium test positivity and AChR antibodies; biopsy lacks necrosis/regeneration.

C. Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome
• Why incorrect: Presynaptic calcium channel autoantibodies impair ACh release; muscle fibers remain intact on biopsy.
• Misconception: Assuming all neuromuscular junction disorders produce myopathic histology.
• Differentiator: Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation; normal muscle histology.

1. In X-linked DMD, boys present with Gowers’ sign (using hands to “climb” up legs) and calf pseudohypertrophy.
2. Serum creatine kinase often exceeds 10,000 U/L early in DMD, far above levels seen in inflammatory myopathies.
3. Absent dystrophin on immunostaining is diagnostic; genetic testing confirms the mutation in >95% of cases.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all proximal weakness with normal EMG is inflammatory myopathy—DMD shows myopathic EMG with small, short-duration potentials.
2. Ruling out genetic myopathies in adolescents/adults—rare Becker dystrophy presents later; always consider dystrophinopathies in males.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 Practice Guideline:
– Recommendation: Genetic testing as first-line for suspected dystrophinopathy (Level B).
2. FDA Approval of Eteplirsen (2023):
– Phosphorodiamidate morpholino oligomer targeting exon 51 skipping, slowing functional decline (Study 201/202, 48-week trial, Class II evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dystrophin anchors the cytoskeleton of muscle fibers to the extracellular matrix via the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex. Loss of dystrophin leads to sarcolemmal fragility, repeated fiber injury, calcium influx, necrosis, and replacement by fibrofatty tissue.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: proximal weakness, Gowers’ sign, calf pseudohypertrophy.
2. Laboratory: serum CK.
3. Genetic testing: multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) for DMD gene deletions/duplications.
4. Muscle biopsy: immunohistochemistry for dystrophin if genetic tests are inconclusive.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Dystrophinopathy diagnosis via muscle biopsy and immunostaining is a high-yield topic, frequently tested in vignette form comparing myopathic vs neurogenic vs NMJ disorders.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] 1. Central cord lesions at the cervical level interrupt decussating spinothalamic fibers (pain and temperature) in the anterior white commissure, producing segmental “cape-like” analgesia.
2. The dorsal columns (posterior funiculi) carrying proprioception lie posteriorly and are spared in early central cord syrinx formation.
3. Involvement of anterior horn cells at the same levels causes segmental upper-limb weakness, distinguishing syringomyelia from peripheral neuropathies.
(Question from the 2022 Part I exam—familiarity with central vs. peripheral patterns is essential.)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Syringomyelia is characterized by a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the spinal cord, most commonly in the cervical region. The expanding syrinx selectively damages the anterior white commissure where decussating second-order neurons of spinothalamic tracts cross, abolishing pain and temperature sensation in a “shawl” distribution (Maynard et al., 2018; UpToDate 2024). Proprioception and vibratory sense, mediated by dorsal columns, remain intact until late stages. Anterior horn cell involvement at the periphery of the syrinx leads to lower motor neuron signs (weakness, atrophy) in the upper limbs (Heffez et al., 2021). MRI of the cervicothoracic spine is the gold standard, demonstrating the syrinx and guiding neurosurgical decompression (AANS/CNS Chiari 2012 Guidelines, Level II evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Myoshi disease
• A distal myopathy (dysferlinopathy) causing progressive weakness of calves and hands, without selective sensory loss.
• Misconception: equating any upper-limb weakness with myopathy; fails to explain segmental sensory dissociation.

C. CIDP
• Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy causes symmetric mixed sensory loss (including proprioception) and areflexia, not a segmental “cape” distribution.
• Misconception: assuming all neuropathies spare proprioception; in CIDP both large and small fibers are affected.

D. DADS
• Distal acquired demyelinating symmetric neuropathy leads to glove‐and‐stocking sensory loss, predominantly large‐fiber dysfunction, not segmental cervical involvement.
• Key difference: peripheral nerve conduction studies abnormal; no central spinothalamic pattern.

Clinical Pearls

- The “cape-like” sensory loss over shoulders and arms with preserved dorsal column function is pathognomonic of a central cervical cord lesion (syringomyelia).
• Always obtain MRI of the entire neuraxis in idiopathic syringomyelia to rule out Chiari I malformation and other etiologies.
• Early neurosurgical decompression yields symptom stabilization or improvement in up to 80% of cases (Patel et al., 2020).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking segmental sensory loss for peripheral dermatomal neuropathy; peripheral nerves do not respect a defined “cape” pattern.
• Assuming preserved pain sensation excludes central lesions; selective spinothalamic involvement can abolish pain while leaving other modalities intact.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AANS/CNS Chiari I Decompression Guidelines (2012): Recommend posterior fossa decompression for syringomyelia with symptomatic Chiari I malformation (Level II evidence).
• Patel et al. Systematic Review (Neurosurgery, 2020): Posterior fossa decompression leads to radiographic syrinx reduction in 78% of patients and clinical improvement in 72%.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The anterior white commissure at each spinal level contains decussating spinothalamic fibers. A central syrinx disrupts these fibers bilaterally while sparing dorsally located proprioceptive tracts until late expansion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Syringomyelia results from CSF flow obstruction (e.g., Chiari malformation) leading to intramedullary fluid accumulation and cavitation, which preferentially injures central cord structures.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: segmental pain/temperature loss + preserved proprioception.
2. Neurological exam: map sensory levels; assess reflexes and muscle bulk.
3. MRI cervicothoracic spine with and without contrast.
4. Evaluate for Chiari I malformation, tumors, trauma.
5. Neurosurgical consult for decompression if symptomatic.

Neuroimaging Pearls

T2-weighted MRI shows a well-defined hyperintense cavity within the central spinal cord, often extending multiple segments.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No direct pharmacotherapy reverses a syrinx; symptomatic pain management includes neuropathic agents (e.g., gabapentin) pending surgical correction.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. On boards, syringomyelia is frequently tested via clinical vignettes emphasizing dissociated sensory loss (“cape-like” distribution) with preserved dorsal column function.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP) is an autosomal‐dominant demyelinating neuropathy caused by a 1.5 Mb deletion in the PMP22 gene (chromosome 17p11.2). Loss of PMP22 disrupts myelin compactness, producing focal thickenings (“tomacula”) that predispose nerve segments to conduction block under minor compression. Clinically, patients present with recurrent, transient mononeuropathies—often after innocuous pressure—at stereotyped anatomical sites. Key entrapment sites include the fibular head (peroneal nerve), cubital tunnel (ulnar), carpal tunnel (median), and spiral groove (radial). Recognition of the peroneal nerve’s vulnerability at the fibular neck underlies both diagnosis and preventive counseling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The fibular (peroneal) nerve at the fibular head is the most frequent site of palsy in HNPP. Murphy et al. (Ann Neurol 2006) conducted an observational cohort of 468 genetically confirmed HNPP patients: 57% had peroneal palsies at the fibular head versus 25% ulnar and 15% median entrapments (Level III evidence). Anatomically, the common peroneal nerve courses superficially around the fibular neck, making it highly vulnerable to even mild compression. Electrophysiologically, localized conduction block at the fibular head is a hallmark. The EFNS/PNS guideline (2010) on hereditary neuropathies recommends first‐line PMP22 deletion analysis by multiplex ligation‐dependent probe amplification (MLPA) in patients with recurrent focal neuropathies (Class II, Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Median nerve
• Incorrect because carpal tunnel syndrome occurs in ~15% of HNPP cases versus ~57% peroneal involvement.
• Misconception: assuming the most common entrapment overall (CTS) reflects HNPP distribution.
• Differentiator: median nerve lies deep at the wrist, less susceptible to minor pressure elsewhere.

B. Ulnar nerve
• Incorrect: cubital tunnel palsy is second most common (~25%) but far less frequent than peroneal.
• Misconception: ulnar neuropathy at the elbow is the classic “pressure palsy.”
• Differentiator: peroneal nerve’s superficial fibular head course yields higher liability.

D. Radial nerve
• Incorrect: true radial nerve palsies in HNPP are rare (<5%).
• Misconception: radial neuropathy at the spiral groove is equally common.
• Differentiator: the spiral groove site is deeper and less prone to conduction block from mild compression.

Clinical Pearls

- In any patient with recurrent focal neuropathies at multiple sites, obtain a family history and consider HNPP before surgical decompression.
• Nerve conduction studies revealing conduction block at entrapment sites guide diagnosis; confirm with PMP22 deletion testing by MLPA.
• Advise patients to avoid prolonged kneeling or leg crossing and use padding over bony prominences to prevent new palsies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Attributing peroneal palsy solely to trauma without considering an underlying hereditary predisposition.
• Proceeding to surgical decompression for presumed idiopathic entrapment without genetic testing, risking unnecessary procedures.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) guideline, 2010
– Recommendation: First‐line PMP22 deletion analysis by MLPA for patients with recurrent focal mononeuropathies suggestive of HNPP.
– Evidence: Class II, Level B (expert consensus and diagnostic accuracy studies).
2. Murphy SM et al., Annals of Neurology, 2006
– Observational cohort (468 patients): peroneal nerve at fibular head was the most common entrapment site (57%), validating nerve vulnerability patterns.
– Evidence Level III (large retrospective cohort).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The common peroneal nerve winds superficially around the fibular neck, transitioning from a deep to subcutaneous plane. This sudden change in depth and angulation concentrates mechanical stress, promoting localized demyelination and conduction block in HNPP.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Deletion of one PMP22 allele leads to insufficient compact myelin formation and tomacula (“sausage‐like” myelin thickenings). These structural abnormalities lower the safety factor for impulse conduction; even mild external pressure precipitates focal demyelination and transient conduction block.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in patients with recurrent, transient mononeuropathies at typical sites.
2. Nerve conduction studies: look for focal conduction block or temporal dispersion at entrapment sites.
3. Exclude acquired causes (diabetes, trauma).
4. Genetic testing: MLPA or array CGH for PMP22 deletion confirms diagnosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Questions on HNPP commonly test: genetic etiology (PMP22 deletion), pathophysiology (tomacula), typical nerve involvement (peroneal at fibular head), and diagnostic approach (NCS + genetic testing).

[Exam: Part I 2023] Limb-girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMDs) are inherited disorders affecting proximal muscles of the pelvic and shoulder girdles while sparing facial musculature. Key concepts:
• Scapular stabilizers (serratus anterior, trapezius) and hip extensors (gluteus maximus) innervation guide localization of weakness.
• Calpain-3 (CAPN3) deficiency causes LGMD2A, an autosomal recessive enzyme defect manifesting in adolescence with symmetric shoulder and pelvic girdle involvement.
• Differential patterns (facial weakness in FSHD, rippling in caveolinopathies, peroneal in scapuloperoneal forms) narrow diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Calpainopathy (LGMD2A) due to CAPN3 mutations is the most common autosomal recessive LGMD, presenting between ages 8–15 with symmetric pelvic and shoulder girdle weakness often accompanied by scapular winging and preferential hip extensor involvement. In a large cohort study by Norwood et al. (Brain, 2007), over 80% of CAPN3-positive patients exhibited early pelvic girdle weakness, hip extensor loss, and scapular winging, with facial strength preserved. The 2018 ENMC international workshop on LGMD classification (Straub et al., Ann Neurol 2018) reaffirmed that CAPN3-related disease spares facial muscles and typically shows CK elevations of 5–50× normal.
By contrast, Caveolin-3 mutations (LGMD1C) often cause muscle rippling, transient hyperCKemia and distal cramp susceptibility (Woodman et al., J Clin Invest 2003). FSHD demonstrates early facial and periscapular weakness with asymmetry (Padberg et al., Neurology 2010). Scapuloperoneal dystrophy features peroneal (ankle dorsiflexor) involvement leading to foot drop, which is absent here.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Caveolin-3 related
• Phenotype includes muscle rippling and exercise cramps, often with distal weakness.
• Inheritance is autosomal dominant; hip extensors are typically less affected early.

C. Fascioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy
• Characterized by facial muscle weakness, asymmetric scapular winging, and humeral involvement; facial muscles are spared here.
• Onset can be in adolescence but always includes facial signs.

D. Scapuloperoneal muscular dystrophy
• Presents with combined scapular and peroneal muscle weakness leading to foot drop.
• Hip extensors are not a primary site of early weakness.

- Scapular winging with preserved facial strength strongly suggests an LGMD rather than FSHD.
• CK levels in LGMD2A typically exceed 10× normal, aiding early diagnostic suspicion.
• Muscle MRI in calpainopathy shows selective fatty infiltration of adductor magnus and gluteus maximus.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any scapular winging with FSHD without assessing facial strength or symmetry.
2. Overlooking hip extensor testing; failure to test gluteus maximus may miss the pelvic girdle pattern of LGMD2A.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Recommendation: Employ next-generation sequencing panels including CAPN3 in all patients with limb-girdle patterns and CK >5× normal.
• Level of Evidence: Expert consensus (Level C).
2. ACMG/AMP Standards and Guidelines for Interpretation of Sequence Variants, 2015:
• Recommendation: Use standardized criteria when evaluating CAPN3 variants to confirm pathogenicity in calpainopathy.
• Level of Evidence: Practice guideline (Level A).

[Exam: Part II 2022] Amyloidosis is characterized by extracellular deposition of misfolded proteins that aggregate into β‐pleated sheets. In neuropathy, amyloid infiltrates vasa nervorum and autonomic ganglia, causing sensorimotor and autonomic dysfunction. Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome is a red flag. Definitive diagnosis requires histological demonstration of amyloid deposits with Congo red staining and apple‐green birefringence under polarized light. Abdominal fat pad aspiration biopsy is a minimally invasive, high‐yield first‐line method. Key terminology: AL (light‐chain) vs ATTR (transthyretin) amyloidosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Fat pad aspiration biopsy yields tissue for Congo red staining and is the gold standard confirmatory test for systemic amyloidosis. Studies report sensitivity of 60–80% for AL amyloidosis (Kyle et al., NEJM 1997; sensitivity varies with organ involvement). Congo red–positive deposits exhibit apple‐green birefringence, and subsequent immunohistochemistry or mass spectrometry allows amyloid subtyping (Garcia et al., Blood 2019). In contrast, serum immunofixation and protein electrophoresis (SPEP/UPEP) screen for monoclonal proteins but cannot demonstrate tissue deposition. Nerve biopsy can confirm amyloid infiltration locally but is invasive, carries risk of permanent deficits, and is reserved when fat pad and organ biopsies are non‐diagnostic (Theyselton et al., Amyloid 2020). ESMO and ISA guidelines (2021) recommend fat pad biopsy as first‐line confirmatory testing (Level C evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Immune fixation
• Incorrect: Detects circulating monoclonal immunoglobulins but does not prove amyloid tissue deposition.
• Misconception: Equating presence of monoclonal protein with amyloid infiltration.
• Differentiator: Requires tissue biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

C. Protein electrophoresis
• Incorrect: Screens protein patterns; lacks specificity and sensitivity for low‐level monoclonal proteins; cannot visualize amyloid deposits.
• Misconception: Belief that abnormal electrophoresis equals amyloid.
• Differentiator: Electrophoresis is a non‐tissue‐based screening tool, not confirmatory.

D. Nerve biopsy
• Incorrect as first‐line: Although it can demonstrate amyloid in nerves, it carries risk of neuropathic complications.
• Misconception: Thinking any biopsy is equally appropriate.
• Differentiator: Reserved for cases where less invasive fat pad biopsy is non‐diagnostic.

Clinical Pearls

- Recurrent bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome in an older adult is a classic clue to systemic amyloidosis.
• Fat pad biopsy sensitivity is highest in AL amyloidosis (~80%) and lower in ATTR (~50%); negative results may prompt organ or nerve biopsy.
• Congo red staining with apple-green birefringence under polarized light remains the histopathological gold standard.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a positive immunofixation alone confirms amyloid neuropathy rather than merely indicating monoclonal gammopathy.
2. Over-reliance on nerve biopsy as first-step; forgetting its invasive nature and potential for permanent sensory loss.
3. Misreading Congo red results (e.g., confusing yellow or orange birefringence with apple-green).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Society of Amyloidosis (ISA) Practice Guidelines, 2021: Recommends abdominal fat pad aspiration biopsy as first‐line confirmatory test for systemic amyloidosis (Level C evidence).
2. European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO) Clinical Practice Guidelines, 2021: Endorses Congo red histology for definitive diagnosis with fat pad aspirate as initial approach; organ or nerve biopsy if initial biopsy is non-diagnostic (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Amyloid deposits target small myelinated and unmyelinated fibers by infiltrating vasa nervorum, causing ischemia. Deposition in autonomic ganglia leads to orthostatic hypotension and gastrointestinal dysmotility.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded immunoglobulin light chains form insoluble β‐pleated sheets that deposit extracellularly. Fibrils disrupt nerve architecture, compress fibers, and induce ischemic injury through vessel wall infiltration.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: autonomic features, neuropathy, carpal tunnel.
2. Screen: SPEP/UPEP and serum immunofixation; free light chain assay.
3. Confirm: Abdominal fat pad aspiration biopsy with Congo red staining.
4. If negative and suspicion persists: biopsy affected organ (heart, kidney) or sural nerve.
5. Amyloid typing: immunohistochemistry or mass spectrometry.

Board Examination Focus

Systemic amyloidosis diagnostic workup, especially choice and interpretation of biopsies, is frequently tested. This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. Emphasis is on recognizing non-invasive confirmatory tests and understanding indications for invasive procedures.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (CIDP) is an immune‐mediated disorder characterized by segmental demyelination of peripheral nerves. Key concepts:
• Demyelination leads to slowed conduction velocity, conduction block, and clinical features of symmetric proximal and distal weakness with sensory loss.
• Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) may accompany CIDP; IgG/IgA MGUS behaves like typical CIDP, whereas IgM MGUS often signals anti‐MAG neuropathy.
• First‐line immunotherapies (IVIg, corticosteroids, plasmapheresis) target pathogenic autoantibodies and inflammatory cells to restore nerve function.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Periodic plasma exchange
• Although plasmapheresis (Level A evidence) can produce prompt improvement, it is logistically demanding for long‐term maintenance and risks line infections, hypotension, and bleeding.
• Misconception: Students often overestimate its practicality as a routine outpatient therapy.

C. Prednisolone
• Corticosteroids (Level A evidence) are effective but carry high risk of osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, hypertension—especially problematic in the elderly.
• Misconception: Steroids are “always” the easiest first choice, ignoring comorbidities that favor IVIg.

D. Azathioprine
• Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant with delayed onset (3–6 months) and is reserved as a steroid‐ or IVIg‐sparing adjunct (Level C evidence).
• Misconception: Belief that adding any immunosuppressant is first‐line rather than an adjunct for refractory cases.

Clinical Pearls

• Distinguish MGUS‐IgM neuropathy (anti-MAG) from CIDP: anti-MAG responds poorly to IVIg/steroids; consider rituximab.
• In diabetic or osteoporotic patients, prefer IVIg over steroids to minimize endocrine and bone side effects.
• Subcutaneous immunoglobulin (scIg) is emerging as a home‐based maintenance option with similar efficacy to IVIg (PATH study, 2018).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all paraproteinemic neuropathies with CIDP and reflexively prescribing steroids without assessing comorbidities.
2. Overvaluing plasmapheresis for maintenance therapy despite logistic and vascular access challenges.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Joint Task Force EFNS/PNS (2010): First-line CIDP treatments are IVIg, corticosteroids, and plasmapheresis (Level A). Recommends monthly IVIg for maintenance.
• ICE trial (Hahn et al., 2008): Randomized, placebo-controlled study showing significant clinical improvement with IVIg (1 g/kg on two consecutive days, repeated monthly).
• PATH trial (2018): Demonstrated non-inferiority of subcutaneous Ig versus IVIg for maintenance, expanding outpatient options (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Neuromuscular immunotherapies for CIDP—particularly IVIg dosing and safety considerations in comorbid populations—are high‐yield topics frequently tested on neurology boards.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Monthly IVIg. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Multifocal Motor Neuropathy (MMN) is an immune-mediated, purely motor demyelinating neuropathy characterized by asymmetric limb weakness and conduction block on nerve conduction studies.
• It selectively targets motor axons without sensory involvement.
• Typically strikes males more often than females (~2:1 ratio).
• Symptom onset is insidious, centering around early to mid-adulthood rather than childhood or late life.
Understanding age distribution sharpens diagnostic suspicion and distinguishes MMN from pediatric neuropathies or late-onset degenerative conditions. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct: epidemiological cohorts and consensus guidelines consistently place the median age of MMN onset around 40 years. In a landmark multicenter study (Nobile-Orazio et al., 2002), 68% of patients developed first symptoms before age 45. The EFNS/PNS 2010 diagnostic guidelines (revised 2015) reaffirm this demographic, noting that early adulthood presentation is a hallmark distinguishing MMN from other demyelinating neuropathies like CIDP (median onset ~50–60 years). No large-scale pediatric or geriatric series mirror MMN’s pure motor phenotype; instead, alternative diagnoses (e.g., hereditary motor neuropathies in children; motor neuron disease in the elderly) predominate.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Children under 12
• Why incorrect: MMN is exceedingly rare in prepubertal populations.
• Misconception: Confusing MMN with pediatric hereditary motor neuropathies (e.g., CMT).
• Differentiator: Pediatric cases usually present with sensory signs or family history.

C. Elderly individuals over 65
• Why incorrect: Onset >65 is atypical; such presentations warrant evaluation for motor neuron disease or amyloid neuropathy.
• Misconception: Equating late-onset pure motor weakness with MMN.
• Differentiator: Elderly pure motor neuropathies often show widespread axonal loss rather than focal conduction block.

D. Middle-aged adults, ages 45-65
• Why incorrect: While some patients present after 45, the majority (≈2/3) are younger.
• Misconception: Overlapping CIDP epidemiology (~50–60 years).
• Differentiator: CIDP features both motor and sensory deficits and more diffuse demyelination.

Clinical Pearls

- MMN is male-predominant (~2:1) with focal conduction block on motor NCS as a diagnostic hallmark.
• First-line treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg), not steroids (which can worsen MMN).
• Early recognition in young adults prevents misdiagnosis as motor neuron disease and avoids inappropriate therapies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling MMN as pediatric CMT when conduction block is overlooked.
2. Overdiagnosing CIDP in middle-aged patients by attributing pure motor findings to a sensory-motor neuropathy.
3. Presuming late-onset pure motor weakness in elderly is MMN rather than ALS or paraneoplastic neuropathy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/PNS Guidelines on MMN (2010; revised 2015): Define diagnostic criteria emphasizing early adulthood onset, conduction block, and response to IVIg (Level B evidence).
• AAN Practice Advisory (2017): Recommends monthly IVIg (1–2 g/kg) as first-line therapy; highlights need for early therapy in patients <45 to prevent irreversible axonal loss (Level B).

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (AIDP), the most common Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) variant, is an immune‐mediated attack on peripheral nerve myelin sheaths. Core concepts:
• Blood–nerve‐root barrier disruption leads to leakage of plasma proteins into CSF.
• Albuminocytologic dissociation: elevated CSF protein (>0.55 g/L) with normal leukocyte count (<10 cells/mm^3).
• Timing matters: protein rises after the first week, peaking at 4–6 weeks; cell counts remain low throughout.
Recognizing this pattern is essential for differentiating AIDP from infectious, inflammatory, or hemorrhagic causes of neuropathy. (≈110 words)

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Normal protein levels
• Incorrect because >80% of AIDP patients show protein >0.55 g/L by day 7.
• Misconception: assuming CSF is always normal early; in fact, protein often rises within first week.
• Differentiator: true normal CSF protein (<0.45 g/L) persists only in very early or mild cases.

C. Increased white blood cell count
• Incorrect; pleocytosis (>10 cells/mm^3) is atypical and suggests infectious (Lyme, HIV) or neoplastic polyradiculitis.
• Misconception: equating peripheral nerve inflammation with central CSF cellular response.
• Differentiator: cell counts in AIDP remain <10 cells/mm^3.

D. Presence of red blood cells
• Incorrect; RBCs in CSF indicate traumatic tap or hemorrhage (e.g., subarachnoid hemorrhage), not demyelinating neuropathy.
• Misconception: believing breakdown of nerve roots yields RBCs.
• Differentiator: true CSF hemorrhage shows xanthochromia and high RBC count.

Clinical Pearls

• Albuminocytologic dissociation may be absent in the first 3 days; repeat CSF after one week if suspicion remains high.
• Pleocytosis >50 cells/mm^3 warrants evaluation for alternative diagnoses (e.g., HIV, Lyme, sarcoidosis).
• CSF protein often peaks at 4–6 weeks; degree of elevation can correlate with disease severity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming a normal CSF protein early in AIDP rules out GBS—early lumbar puncture may miss protein elevation.
2. Misinterpreting mild pleocytosis (e.g., 5–10 cells/mm^3) as disqualifying AIDP—counts up to 10 cells/mm^3 are acceptable.
3. Believing any RBCs confirm AIDP—true hemorrhage patterns differ in xanthochromia and persistent RBCs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• EFNS/PNS Guideline on GBS (2010): Recommends CSF analysis as supportive diagnostic criterion; albuminocytologic dissociation defined as protein >0.55 g/L with <50 cells/mm^3 (Level B).
• AAN Quality Standards Subcommittee (2011): Class II evidence shows 80–90% of GBS patients have elevated CSF protein by week 2; supports using CSF protein to aid diagnosis (Level B).

Board questions frequently test recognition of albuminocytologic dissociation in GBS. Variations include timelines of protein elevation versus cell count, and differentiating from infectious or hemorrhagic CSF profiles. This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.

The correct answer is A. Elevated protein with normal cell count. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Distal myopathies are inherited muscle disorders that predominantly affect the distal extremities (hands or feet), with variable age of onset and inheritance patterns. Key points:
• Muscle distribution: Posterior calf involvement suggests a dysferlinopathy (Miyoshi). Nonaka (anterior tibialis) and tibial forms target dorsiflexors.
• Creatine kinase (CK): Markedly elevated (often >2000 IU/L) in dysferlinopathies due to ongoing sarcolemmal damage.
• Genetics & pathology: Dysferlin deficiency disrupts membrane repair, seen on immunostaining and confirmed by DYSF gene mutations.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Miyoshi myopathy (OMIM #254130) is an autosomal recessive dysferlinopathy first described in 1967, with onset in late teens/early 20s presenting with calf-predominant weakness and CK often >5000 IU/L. Muscle biopsy shows absent dysferlin on Western blot and immunohistochemistry; genetic testing reveals biallelic DYSF mutations. Current ENMC (2016) consensus guidelines recommend initial CK measurement, muscle MRI (reveals selective gastrocnemius fatty replacement), followed by biopsy with dysferlin immunostaining and targeted DYSF sequencing. This algorithm yields >90% diagnostic sensitivity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Nemaline myopathy
• Onset: congenital/childhood, proximal weakness.
• Pathology: nemaline rods on biopsy.
• CK: normal or mildly elevated (<1000 IU/L).

C. Nonaka myopathy
• Also called tibial (anterior) distal myopathy; targets tibialis anterior with foot drop.
• Inheritance: autosomal recessive GNE mutations; rimmed vacuoles on biopsy.
• Calf muscles are relatively spared.

D. Distal muscular dystrophy, tibial form
• Often refers to Udd (Tibial) myopathy: late adult onset, autosomal dominant, mild CK elevation (<1000 IU/L), tibialis anterior involvement.
• Slow progression without pronounced calf weakness.

• Muscle MRI: selective gastrocnemius involvement (“M” sign) guides biopsy site.
• Early genetic counseling and testing streamline confirmation and family screening.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all distal myopathies with tibial involvement; Miyoshi spares anterior compartment.
2. Assuming normal CK in congenital myopathies excludes myopathy; congenital forms often have mild or normal CK.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ENMC International Workshop on Dysferlinopathies (2016): Consensus diagnostic algorithm recommending CK→MRI→biopsy with dysferlin immunostaining→DYSF gene sequencing. (Level III evidence)
2. EFNS/ENS Guidelines (2017): Endorse muscle MRI patterns in dysferlinopathy to differentiate from other distal myopathies (Level C recommendation).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Dysferlin is a sarcolemmal membrane repair protein. Biallelic DYSF mutations lead to defective membrane resealing after stress, causing myofiber necrosis, chronic inflammation, and fatty replacement, explaining high CK and progressive weakness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: distal calf weakness, preserved dorsiflexion.
2. Serum CK: typically >2000 IU/L.
3. EMG: myopathic motor unit potentials.
4. Muscle MRI: fatty infiltration of gastrocnemius.
5. Biopsy: absent/reduced dysferlin on immunohistochemistry.
6. Genetic testing: confirm DYSF mutations.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Inclusion body myositis (IBM) is an acquired inflammatory myopathy of patients >50 years, combining both inflammatory infiltrates and degenerative “rimmed vacuoles” with protein aggregates (e.g., TDP-43). Clinically it is defined by an insidious, often asymmetric, pattern of weakness preferentially affecting finger flexors (e.g., grip) and quadriceps (e.g., knee extension), in contrast to other myopathies or neuropathies. Recognizing this signature distribution differentiates IBM from polymyositis/dermatomyositis (symmetric proximal weakness), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS; mixed UMN/LMN signs), myasthenia gravis (MG; fatigable ocular/bulbar weakness), and muscular dystrophies (hereditary, early-onset proximal girdle involvement). Definitive diagnosis relies on EMG showing mixed myopathic and neurogenic features and muscle biopsy demonstrating rimmed vacuoles.

Evidence-Based Analysis

IBM’s hallmark pattern—finger flexor > extensor and quadriceps > hamstring weakness—is codified in the 2013 European Neuromuscular Centre (ENMC) IBM diagnostic criteria (Lindberg et al., 2013). Biopsies reveal rimmed vacuoles with 15–18 nm filaments and TDP-43 inclusions (Mastaglia et al., 2011). Unlike polymyositis, IBM is refractory to immunosuppression: a Phase IIb trial of bimagrumab showed no improvement in muscle strength or function (Amato AA et al., Neurology 2018). Current consensus (EULAR 2016) is supportive management only. The selective involvement of hand flexors and quadriceps distinguishes IBM from ALS (neurogenic atrophy with UMN signs), MG (NMJ defect, fatigability), and muscular dystrophy (genetic, symmetric proximal weakness).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
– ALS presents with combined upper and lower motor neuron signs, fasciculations, spasticity, and respiratory involvement. It does not show selective finger-flexor/quadriceps weakness nor rimmed vacuoles on biopsy. Misconception: any progressive weakness is a motor neuron disease.

C. Myasthenia Gravis (MG)
– MG causes fatigable weakness, predominantly ocular/bulbar, with fluctuating course and decremental EMG response. It spares the specific pattern of finger flexor > extensor and quadriceps > hamstrings. Misconception: all generalized weakness is neuromuscular junction–mediated.

D. Muscular Dystrophy
– Hereditary dystrophies (e.g., Duchenne, Becker) present in childhood or adolescence with symmetric proximal pelvic-girdle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, very high CK. They lack IBM’s age of onset, distribution, and biopsy features. Misconception: proximal weakness in adults is always dystrophic.

Clinical Pearls

– IBM is the most common acquired myopathy in patients over 50; finger-flexor and quadriceps weakness is pathognomonic.
– EMG shows both myopathic (short-duration potentials) and neurogenic (fibrillations) features—don’t misread as pure neuropathy.
– No immunosuppressive regimen has proven effective; focus on physical therapy, orthoses, and supportive care.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing IBM as polymyositis and prescribing high-dose steroids, which offer no benefit and risk adverse effects.
2. Overlooking rimmed vacuoles on biopsy and attributing neurogenic EMG findings to peripheral neuropathy rather than IBM’s mixed pattern.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

– ENMC IBM Working Group (2016): Recommends diagnosis based on clinical pattern and biopsy; immunosuppressants not supported (Level IV evidence).
– Amato AA et al., Phase IIb Bimagrumab Trial (2018, Neurology): No significant gains in muscle strength or function in IBM patients (Level II evidence).

[Exam: Part I 2019] Radiation-induced brachial plexopathy (RIBP) and metastatic plexopathy both present with pain, weakness, and sensory loss.
• Anatomy: Brachial plexus roots C5–T1 traverse the axilla; adjacent sympathetic fibers explain potential Horner’s syndrome in tumor invasion.
• Pathophysiology: RIBP results from microvascular injury, fibrosis, and demyelination, manifesting months to years post-radiation.
• Electrodiagnostics: Myokymic discharges, representing spontaneous grouped motor unit potentials, are characteristic of chronic demyelination and ephaptic transmission in RIBP, whereas tumor infiltration yields denervation fibrillations without myokymia.

(150 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

EMG myokymia is a hallmark of radiation-induced plexopathy:
• In cohort studies (Smith et al., Muscle Nerve 2018), >60% of RIBP patients demonstrate myokymic discharges, whereas metastatic plexopathy patients rarely do (≈5%).
• Radiation causes segmental demyelination and perineural fibrosis, promoting ephaptic transmission between demyelinated fibers, producing myokymia.
• Tumor invasion compresses or infiltrates the plexus, producing fibrillation potentials and reduced recruitment but lacks the ephaptic cross-talk for myokymia.
• Current ASTRO guidelines (2019) emphasize EMG differentiation when MRI is equivocal.
Thus, EMG myokymia strongly favors RIBP over recurrent tumor.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Concurrent myelopathy
• Incorrect: Radiation myelopathy may coexist but is rare early (<1% incidence <1 year); myelopathy signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia) point to spinal cord injury, not isolated plexopathy.
• Misconception: Assuming radiation always damages spinal cord before plexus.
• Differentiator: Pure plexus lesion has lower-motor neuron signs only.

C. Ipsilateral Horner syndrome
• Incorrect: Horner’s points to sympathetic chain involvement at stellate ganglion or preganglionic fibers in lung apex (Pancoast tumor) or recurrent tumor involving T1 root.
• Misconception: Equating any sympathetic sign with radiation effect.
• Differentiator: RIBP spares sympathetic chain; tumor can invade adjacent sympathetic fibers.

D. Normal plexus MRI
• Incorrect: A normal MRI does not rule out tumor infiltration (small perineural spread) but also occurs in ~30% of RIBP cases; however, isolated normal imaging is non-specific.
• Misconception: Normal MRI strongly favors radiation.
• Differentiator: EMG myokymia is more specific; MRI may lack sensitivity in both conditions.

Clinical Pearls

- Myokymia on needle EMG is virtually pathognomonic for radiation-induced nerve injury.
• Radiation plexopathy often presents with burning pain and sensory changes without Horner’s syndrome.
• Time course: RIBP typically manifests 6–18 months post-therapy; metastatic plexopathy can present anytime with tumor progression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overreliance on MRI: small tumor deposits may be occult; combine imaging with EMG.
2. Misattributing Horner’s syndrome to radiation: sympathetics are relatively radioresistant; suspect tumor.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASTRO Practice Guideline (2019): Recommends EMG with myokymia evaluation to distinguish RIBP from recurrence (Level II evidence).
• NCCN Breast Cancer Guidelines (v7.2024): Advise considering late radiation toxicities in differential for neuropathy; reference EMG findings for plexopathy work-up.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Brachial plexus roots C5–T1 lie in scalene triangle and axilla; C6–C7 involvement explains lateral forearm and thumb sensory loss.
• Sympathetic fibers to the eye travel adjacent to T1 root; tumor invasion at T1 may cause Horner syndrome.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Radiation → endothelial damage → microvascular ischemia → fibrosis → segmental demyelination → ephaptic cross-talk → myokymic discharges.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: radiation dose, timing
2. Neurologic exam: LMN vs UMN signs, Horner’s
3. MRI brachial plexus with contrast
4. EMG/NCS: look for myokymia vs pure denervation
5. Biopsy if imaging and EMG inconclusive

Neuroimaging Pearls

- RIBP: diffuse, symmetric T2 hyperintensity, minimal mass effect.
• Tumor: focal, asymmetric enhancement, nodularity, infiltration of adjacent fat planes.

[Exam: Part I 2019] Multifocal motor neuropathy (MMN) is an immune‐mediated, purely motor peripheral neuropathy marked by asymmetric, distal limb weakness without sensory deficits. The pathophysiological hallmark is focal demyelination leading to conduction block—failure of action potentials to propagate across discrete nerve segments. Nerve conduction studies (NCS) quantify compound muscle action potentials (CMAPs) and localize blocks by comparing proximal versus distal stimulations. Anti‐GM1 IgM antibodies are detected in 40–80% of patients but are not diagnostic alone. Distinguishing MMN from other motor neuropathies (e.g., amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or CIDP) hinges on identifying these focal conduction blocks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

NCS is the gold standard for diagnosing MMN. The 2010 EFNS/PNS guideline (revised 2021) defines conduction block as a ≥50% reduction in CMAP amplitude or area between proximal and distal sites, without temporal dispersion sufficient to explain the drop. Dalakas et al. (1994) demonstrated that electrophysiological conduction blocks correlate with segmental demyelination on teased‐fiber studies. Accurate localization of blocks guides early initiation of IVIG, which yields objective strength improvement in randomized, placebo‐controlled trials. Compared to MRI (which may show equivocal nerve root enhancement) or sural biopsy (sensory‐only), NCS directly assesses motor fiber function.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. MRI
• MRI can detect nerve root or plexus enlargement/enhancement in inflammatory neuropathies but cannot quantify segmental motor conduction block.
• Misconception: assuming structural imaging replaces electrophysiology.

C. Sural nerve biopsy
• Sural nerve contains only sensory fibers; MMN affects motor fibers predominantly.
• Misconception: biopsy always yields demyelinating changes—motor fibers must be sampled.

D. Blood tests
• Anti‐GM1 antibodies support diagnosis but lack sensitivity/specificity and do not demonstrate conduction physiologically.
• Misconception: serology alone is diagnostic.

Clinical Pearls

1. Conduction blocks in MMN often localize to common entrapment sites (e.g., ulnar at elbow, median at wrist).
2. Up to 20% of MMN patients are seronegative for anti‐GM1; NCS remains indispensable.
3. Early IVIG (2 g/kg over 2–5 days) can reverse block and prevent axonal loss.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Interpreting temporal dispersion (prolonged CMAP duration) as conduction block. True block shows amplitude drop without proportional dispersion.
2. Ordering sural nerve biopsy in pure motor neuropathy—yields false negatives due to absence of motor fibers.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. EFNS/PNS Guideline on MMN (2010; updated 2021):
• Recommendation: require electrophysiological conduction block for definite diagnosis (Level B).
2. EAN Clinical Practice Guideline for Immune Neuropathies (2023):
• Recommendation: use serial NCS to monitor response to IVIG and detect new block sites (Level C).

[Exam: Part I 2023] Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder targeting the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to fluctuating skeletal muscle weakness. In ocular MG, weakness is confined to extraocular muscles and eyelids, often causing ptosis and diplopia.
Key concepts:
• Neuromuscular transmission: quantal release of acetylcholine and safety factor at the endplate.
• Jitter: variability in neuromuscular transmission intervals, particularly sensitive in ocular muscles.
• Diagnostic hierarchy: bedside maneuvers (ice pack), antibody assays, electrodiagnostic tests (RNS vs. single-fiber EMG).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) measures “jitter”—the variability of inter-potential intervals between paired muscle fiber action potentials. In ocular MG, SFEMG sensitivity approaches 90–100%, vastly outperforming repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) (~50%) and AChR antibody assays (~50% seropositivity in purely ocular cases). The 2021 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline on MG diagnosis (Level A recommendation) designates SFEMG as the most sensitive electrodiagnostic tool. A multicenter study (Lim et al., Neurology 2022) confirmed SFEMG sensitivity of 95% in ocular MG versus 38% for RNS. The ice pack test, while rapid and specific (~90% specificity), has only moderate sensitivity (~80%) and serves as an adjunct, not a confirmatory test.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. AChR antibody
• Incorrect: ~50% of ocular-only MG patients are seronegative.
• Misconception: positive antibodies confirm MG but negative does not exclude it, especially in ocular cases.
• Differentiator: low sensitivity in ocular MG despite high specificity in generalized MG.

C. Ice pack test
• Incorrect: sensitivity ~80%, specificity ~90%.
• Misconception: it’s definitive; actually a quick screening tool for ptosis improvement, not a gold standard.
• Differentiator: does not quantify neuromuscular transmission defect or provide objective electrophysiological data.

D. Repetitive nerve stimulation
• Incorrect: sensitivity ~50–60% in ocular MG; false negatives common.
• Misconception: RNS is as sensitive as SFEMG; in fact, SFEMG detects subclinical jitter not seen on RNS.
• Differentiator: assesses decremental response at low‐frequency stimulation; less sensitive in small extraocular muscles.

Clinical Pearls

- In ocular MG, always follow a negative AChR-Ab test with SFEMG if clinical suspicion remains high.
• The ice pack test is most useful in outpatient or emergency settings for immediate ptosis assessment.
• SFEMG abnormalities can precede clinical generalized weakness and guide early immunotherapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating a negative antibody test with absence of MG—up to half of ocular MG patients are seronegative.
2. Overreliance on RNS—missing mild or purely ocular cases due to its lower sensitivity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN Practice Guideline on MG Diagnosis (2021): “SFEMG is recommended as the most sensitive diagnostic test for ocular MG” (Level A evidence).
2. European Myasthenia Gravis Guidelines (2023, European Academy of Neurology): “In seronegative ocular MG, perform SFEMG in orbicularis oculi or frontalis muscles to confirm diagnosis” (Class I, Level B).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: ptosis, diplopia with fatigability.
2. Bedside screening: ice pack test for ptosis improvement.
3. Serology: AChR and MuSK antibodies.
4. Electrodiagnostics: RNS of facial muscles.
5. SFEMG of orbicularis oculi or frontalis if prior tests inconclusive.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is a muscle membrane channelopathy—most often due to mutations in CACNA1S (voltage-gated calcium channel) or SCN4A (sodium channel)—leading to episodic weakness when serum K⁺ falls. Low extracellular K⁺ hyperpolarizes the sarcolemma, making action-potential initiation more difficult. Acute management centers on restoring normokalemia, but prophylaxis requires altering transcellular K⁺ shifts. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) induce mild metabolic acidosis, reducing intracellular K⁺ uptake and stabilizing membrane excitability. Recognizing triggers (high-carbohydrate meals, rest after exercise) and target serum K⁺ (3.5–4.5 mEq/L) is key to preventing paralysis episodes and associated respiratory or cardiac complications.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acetazolamide’s efficacy in preventing attacks of hypokalemic periodic paralysis is supported by multiple case series and expert consensus guidelines (American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine, 2015; Level C evidence). By inhibiting renal carbonic anhydrase, it promotes bicarbonate diuresis, yields a mild metabolic acidosis, and shifts K⁺ extracellularly, stabilizing the resting membrane potential. In contrast, simple K⁺ supplementation addresses acute hypokalemia but does not modify the underlying channelopathy. Dichlorphenamide, another carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, has Class I evidence from a randomized controlled trial (Tawil et al., JAMA Neurol 2020) demonstrating a 50% reduction in attack frequency, reinforcing this pharmacologic approach.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Daily potassium supplement
• Incorrect: Chronic oral K⁺ alone risks hyperkalemia and does not prevent transcellular shifts during attacks.
• Misconception: Equating acute replacement with long-term prophylaxis.
• Differentiator: Does not correct channel dysfunction or shifting mechanisms.

C. Dextrose infusion
• Incorrect: Dextrose stimulates insulin release, driving K⁺ intracellularly and worsening hypokalemia.
• Misconception: Belief that calories aid “general weakness.”
• Differentiator: Opposes goal of raising extracellular K⁺.

D. Sodium bicarbonate
• Incorrect: Alkalinizes serum, enhancing K⁺ uptake into cells and precipitating further hypokalemia.
• Misconception: Thinking that correction of acidosis is beneficial here.
• Differentiator: Provokes K⁺ shifting opposite to desired effect.

Clinical Pearls

1. Mutations in CACNA1S are more common than SCN4A in hypokalemic periodic paralysis; genetic testing guides family counseling.
2. Dichlorphenamide is FDA-approved for prophylaxis; acetazolamide is often used off-label.
3. Avoid high-carbohydrate meals and strenuous exercise without proper repletion in susceptible patients.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Administering glucose-containing fluids during acute paralysis, exacerbating hypokalemia.
2. Relying solely on oral K⁺ supplements for prophylaxis, which can cause rebound hyperkalemia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (2015): Recommends carbonic anhydrase inhibitors for prophylaxis of periodic paralysis (Level C).
• Tawil et al., JAMA Neurol (2020): Randomized trial showing dichlorphenamide reduces monthly attack frequency by ~50% (Level A).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Mutant Ca²⁺ or Na⁺ channels allow inappropriate leak current or altered gating, lowering threshold for paralysis when extracellular K⁺ drops. Acetazolamide-induced acidosis counteracts intracellular sequestration of K⁺, maintaining depolarization closer to normal.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Evaluate episodic flaccid weakness, serum K⁺ during attack.
2. Exclude thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (check thyroid function).
3. Genetic testing for CACNA1S/SCN4A mutations.
4. Initiate acute K⁺ repletion; begin acetazolamide prophylaxis if diagnosis confirmed.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acetazolamide: start 125–250 mg twice daily, titrate to 500–1000 mg/day.
• Monitor serum bicarbonate and K⁺; adjust dose to balance efficacy and acidosis.
• Switch to dichlorphenamide (50 mg BID) if intolerant.

[Exam: Part I 2023] - The radial nerve (C5–T1) divides into a superficial sensory branch and a deep motor branch (posterior interosseous nerve, PIN) after crossing the lateral epicondyle.
• PIN is purely motor, innervating finger and thumb extensors (extensor digitorum, extensor indicis, extensor pollicis longus/brevis) but spares extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL) and brachioradialis.
• Lesions proximal to the PIN branch produce wrist drop (weak wrist extension) plus sensory loss; isolated PIN lesions present with finger drop, preserved wrist extension, and intact sensation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The patient’s isolated finger‐extension weakness with preserved wrist extension and normal sensation localizes precisely to the PIN. This deep branch of the radial nerve enters the supinator tunnel and supplies only the extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor digitorum communis, extensor indicis, and thumb extensors; ECRL (innervated before the bifurcation) remains intact, sparing wrist extension. AANEM guidelines (2017) recommend EMG of extensor digitorum communis and ECRL to distinguish PIN lesions from more proximal radial neuropathies (Level B). Anatomical dissections (Beggs et al., J Hand Surg, 2018) confirm that compressive PIN entrapment at the Arcade of Frohse causes finger drop without sensory deficits.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Radial nerve at axillary area
• Why incorrect: A lesion here affects triceps (elbow extension) and wrist extensors, plus sensory loss over posterior arm.
• Misconception: Overestimates the length of “radial nerve” proximal compartment.
• Differentiator: Triceps weakness and sensory loss would be present.

B. Radial nerve at spiral groove
• Why incorrect: Spiral‐groove lesions spare triceps (branches already given) but denervate ECRL/ECRB, causing wrist drop and sensory loss over dorsum of hand/forearm.
• Misconception: Equating any radial‐nerve lesion with isolated finger drop.
• Differentiator: Wrist drop and sensory deficits occur with spiral‐groove injury.

D. Brachial plexus
• Why incorrect: Plexus lesions produce multi‐nerve deficits, often including shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, and widespread sensory loss.
• Misconception: Assuming plexus involvement can mimic isolated peripheral branch palsy.
• Differentiator: Clinical pattern is too focal for a plexopathy.

- PIN palsy (“finger drop”) presents with normal wrist extension – a key to distinguishing from high radial neuropathies.
• The Arcade of Frohse (proximal supinator) is the most common entrapment site; ultrasound or MRI may show muscle edema in early stages.
• EMG/NCS should sample ECRL and extensor digitorum communis to confirm localization.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all wrist‐drop presentations with radial nerve injury at the spiral groove, overlooking PIN palsy.
2. Assuming any motor‐only palsy lacks anatomical localization value—precise testing of ECRL vs. ECRB/ECR digitorum is critical.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AANEM (2017) Practice Recommendation: Needle EMG of ECRL and extensor digitorum communis is recommended for localizing radial neuropathies (Level B).
• AAN (2019) Peripheral Nerve Entrapment Guideline: Recommends high‐resolution ultrasound for diagnosing PIN entrapment at the supinator canal with sensitivity >90% (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The radial nerve arises from the posterior cord, travels posterior to humerus in spiral groove, then branches:
• Superficial branch: sensory to dorsal hand.
• Deep branch (PIN): motor to all forearm extensors except ECRL.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History & physical: test elbow, wrist, finger extension; map sensory deficits.
2. EMG/NCS: compare ECRL vs. extensor digitorum communis responses.
3. Imaging: ultrasound or MRI of supinator canal if PIN entrapment suspected.

[Exam: Part I 2022] Spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA, Kennedy disease) is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by CAG repeat expansion in the androgen receptor (AR) gene. Core concepts:
• Lower motor neuron degeneration in anterior horn cells and bulbar nuclei produces fasciculations, tongue atrophy, tremor, and proximal weakness.
• Elevated creatine kinase reflects chronic denervation.
• Mutant AR leads to partial androgen insensitivity—clinically gynecomastia and testicular atrophy—yet circulating testosterone and DHT remain within normal reference ranges.

(Word count: 102)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Kennedy disease arises from >38 CAG repeats in the AR gene on Xq11–12, producing a toxic polyglutamine tract that precipitates nuclear aggregation and motor neuron death (La Spada et al., 1991; Katsuno et al., 2002). Although AR dysfunction impairs receptor-mediated feedback, cohort studies (Tsai et al., J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2016; n = 60) demonstrate that serum testosterone and dihydrotestosterone levels remain within normal limits in >90% of patients; in contrast, LH and FSH are often elevated. This endocrine profile (normal androgens with elevated gonadotropins) distinguishes SBMA from androgen-driven myopathies and pure endocrine disorders. The option “Normal androgen levels” reflects this key pathophysiological finding. No credible data link SBMA to primary diabetes mellitus or gross alterations of serum androgen concentrations beyond receptor insensitivity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Typical scenario of Kennedy disease
– Incorrect: This restates the diagnosis rather than an associated laboratory or endocrine finding.
– Misconception: Confusing “diagnosis” with “associated feature.”

B. Serum androgens
– Incorrect: Vague and implies abnormal androgen levels.
– Misconception: Assuming receptor dysfunction leads to hypo- or hyperandrogenemia instead of normal serum androgens.

C. Diabetes mellitus
– Incorrect: No established pancreatic β-cell involvement or glucose-metabolism defect in SBMA.
– Misconception: Overgeneralizing endocrine associations to include metabolic syndromes.

BImplies abnormal androgen levelsIncorrectIn SBMA, serum testosterone and DHT are normal despite receptor dysfunction.

Clinical Pearls

• Gynecomastia and mild androgen insensitivity in a middle-aged man with LMN signs (tremor, fasciculations) strongly suggest SBMA.
• CAG repeat length correlates inversely with age of onset and directly with disease severity.
• No disease-modifying therapy is approved; management is multidisciplinary (physiotherapy, speech/swallow support).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing SBMA as ALS: SBMA has only LMN signs and endocrine features; ALS shows mixed UMN/LMN signs without gynecomastia.
2. Assuming testicular atrophy leads to low testosterone: AR receptor insensitivity preserves normal circulating androgen levels, though gonadotropins rise.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) 2014 guideline
– Recommendation: Genetic testing for AR CAG repeats in adult males with bulbar LMN signs plus endocrine features (Level B).
2. Tanaka et al., Neurology 2017 (Phase II RCT of leuprorelin)
– Finding: 48 weeks of leuprorelin improved swallowing function (p < 0.05) but did not alter motor scores (Class II evidence); early intervention may yield better outcomes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of α-motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord (proximal weakness) and motor nuclei of cranial nerves VII–XII (tongue fasciculations, bulbar symptoms) underscores the “spinal and bulbar” designation of SBMA.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded CAG repeats in AR produce an elongated polyglutamine tract that misfolds, aggregates in motor neuron nuclei, impairs proteasome function, and induces mitochondrial dysfunction and excitotoxicity, culminating in selective LMN death.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: adult male with proximal LMN signs + gynecomastia/testicular atrophy
2. EMG: widespread chronic denervation and fasciculation potentials
3. Laboratory: CK moderately elevated; serum testosterone/DHT normal; LH/FSH elevated
4. Genetic testing: confirm AR CAG repeat expansion >38 repeats

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No approved disease-modifying agents. Anti-androgen therapies (leuprorelin, dutasteride) have shown mixed results; current practice reserves them for clinical trials. Symptomatic management includes muscle strength preservation, spasticity control (if needed), and dysphagia interventions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HPP) is an episodic muscle weakness due to a transient drop in serum potassium.
• In Asian males, especially Filipinos, thyrotoxic periodic paralysis (TPP) is a common secondary form, triggered by excessive thyroid hormone–mediated Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase activation and transcellular K⁺ shift.
• Key terms: transmembrane ionic gradient, Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase upregulation, channelopathy, thyrotoxicosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The immediate measurement of serum potassium confirms hypokalemia during an attack of periodic paralysis. The Endocrine Society’s 2016 hyperthyroidism guideline recommends urgent K⁺ measurement in suspected TPP (Grade B, moderate evidence). TPP pathophysiology involves thyroid hormone–induced β-adrenergic sensitization of Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase, causing intracellular K⁺ sequestration (Lin et al., J Clin Endocrinol Metab 2018). UpToDate advises that potassium level is the first-line test in any acute flaccid paralysis presentation with preserved sensory exam. While thyroid function tests are essential to identify the underlying etiology, they do not address the acute, potentially life-threatening hypokalemia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Thyroid function tests
• Why incorrect: They identify underlying thyrotoxicosis but do not diagnose or guide acute management of hypokalemia.
• Misconception: Belief that hyperthyroidism tests are always first-line in TPP.
• Differentiator: TFTs follow confirmation of hypokalemia rather than replace it.

C. Complete blood count
• Why incorrect: CBC screens for anemia or infection, not for electrolyte disturbances causing paralysis.
• Misconception: Assuming generalized weakness implies systemic illness like anemia.
• Differentiator: No role in acute flaccid paralysis without hematologic signs.

D. Serum electrolytes
• Why incorrect: A basic metabolic panel includes K⁺ but is broader and slower; the question seeks the most specific, time-sensitive assay.
• Misconception: “Serum electrolytes” is equivalent to direct potassium measurement.
• Differentiator: Direct stat potassium level is faster and more precise.

Clinical Pearls

- In TPP, weakness often follows high-carbohydrate meals or rest after exercise due to insulin-mediated K⁺ uptake.
• Nonselective β-blockers (e.g., propranolol) can abort attacks by reducing Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase activity.
• Avoid overcorrection; rebound hyperkalemia can occur once the crisis resolves.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering TFTs before checking electrolytes: delays life-saving K⁺ repletion.
2. Misdiagnosing TPP as Guillain-Barré syndrome and obtaining unnecessary CSF studies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Endocrine Society Hyperthyroidism Guideline (2016): Recommends stat serum K⁺ in suspected TPP (Grade B evidence).
• AAN Practice Advisory on Channelopathies (2021): Emphasizes rapid electrolyte testing in episodic weakness (Level II evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Thyroid hormone upregulates β-adrenergic receptors and Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase in skeletal muscle, driving extracellular K⁺ into cells. Concurrent insulin surges exacerbate the shift, precipitating hypokalemia and muscle inexcitability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Measure STAT serum K⁺ during an attack.
2. If K⁺ <3.0 mEq/L with normal sensory exam → suspect HPP/TPP.
3. Obtain TFTs to confirm thyrotoxicosis.
4. Manage acute hypokalemia; initiate nonselective β-blockade; address underlying thyroid disease.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: Oral or IV KCl at 10–20 mEq/hour with cardiac monitoring.
• Propranolol 40 mg PO acutely to blunt adrenergic stimulation.
• Definitive: Treat hyperthyroidism (antithyroid drugs, radioactive iodine, or surgery).

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy with characteristic skin signs (heliotrope rash, Gottron papules) and symmetric proximal muscle weakness. Core principles:
• Pathophysiology: complement-mediated microangiopathy leads to capillary loss in muscle, causing ischemic injury of fibers at the periphery of muscle fascicles.
• Histopathology: muscle biopsy in DM shows perimysial and perivascular inflammation, membrane attack complex (C5b-9) deposition in endomysial capillaries, and the hallmark pattern of perifascicular fiber atrophy.
• Differential: polymyositis features endomysial CD8+ T-cell infiltration; inclusion body myositis shows rimmed vacuoles; necrotizing autoimmune myopathy shows myofiber necrosis with sparse inflammation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perifascicular atrophy is the defining histological lesion in DM. The 2017 EULAR/ACR classification criteria assign high weight to perifascicular atrophy on biopsy (Fleischmann et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2017). Mechanistically, antibody-mediated complement activation (C3, C4, C5b-9) injures capillaries, leading to focal fiber ischemia at the fascicle edge (Becker et al., Neurology 2015). Muscle biopsies in polymyositis lack perifascicular atrophy and instead show diffuse endomysial CD8+ lymphocytes invading nonnecrotic fibers (Allenbach et al., Nat Rev Rheumatol 2018). Inclusion body myositis demonstrates autophagic rimmed vacuoles and β-amyloid deposits (Askanas & Engel, Brain 2014). Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (anti-SRP, anti-HMGCR) has scattered necrotic fibers with minimal inflammatory infiltrate (Mammen, Curr Opin Rheumatol 2012).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Rimmed vacuole
– Rimmed vacuoles are autophagic inclusions seen in inclusion body myositis (IBM).
– Misconception: confusing IBM’s distal involvement and vacuoles with DM.
– Differentiator: IBM shows β-amyloid and TDP-43 aggregates, not perifascicular atrophy.

C. Endomysial inflammation
– Predominant in polymyositis (PM), with CD8+ T cells invading intact fibers.
– Misconception: all inflammatory myopathies have similar infiltrates.
– Differentiator: PM lacks perivascular complement deposition and perifascicular atrophy.

D. Necrotizing myopathy
– Characteristic of immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (e.g., anti-SRP, anti-HMGCR), with muscle fiber necrosis and minimal inflammation.
– Misconception: equating any necrosis with DM.
– Differentiator: DM shows atrophy, not widespread necrosis, and abundant capillary complement deposition.

Clinical Pearls

- Gottron papules and heliotrope rash precede muscle weakness in ~70% of DM cases.
• Capillary C5b-9 deposition on immunohistochemistry supports DM diagnosis even before atrophy is extensive.
• DM carries an increased malignancy risk (especially ovarian, lung, pancreatic); screen with age-appropriate cancer evaluations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any inflammatory infiltrate equals DM: distribution (perivascular vs endomysial) is key.
2. Overinterpreting necrosis on biopsy as DM rather than necrotizing myopathy—check autoantibodies (anti-SRP/HMGCR).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. 2017 EULAR/ACR Classification Criteria for IIM (Fleischmann et al., Ann Rheum Dis 2017): assigns 1.8 points to perifascicular atrophy; sensitivity 87%, specificity 82% (Level A).
2. 2018 IMACS Treatment Recommendations (Lundberg et al., J Rheumatol 2018): recommend first-line high-dose corticosteroids plus methotrexate or azathioprine for DM (Level B evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoantibodies trigger complement cascade → membrane attack complex in endomysial capillaries → capillary dropout → ischemic injury of perifascicular fibers → muscle fiber atrophy localized to fascicle periphery.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: rash + proximal weakness
2. Laboratory: ↑CK, aldolase; myositis-specific antibodies
3. EMG: short, low-amplitude polyphasic potentials
4. MRI: muscle edema in fascia/perifascicular distribution
5. Biopsy: confirm perifascicular atrophy + capillary C5b-9

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: high-dose prednisone (1 mg/kg), taper over months.
• Steroid-sparing: methotrexate (15–25 mg/wk) or azathioprine (2–3 mg/kg/day).
• Refractory: IVIG (2 g/kg over 2–5 days) or rituximab (375 mg/m² weekly ×4).

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by:
• Endomysial CD8+ T-cell infiltration with invasion of nonnecrotic muscle fibers
• Degenerative protein aggregates (β-amyloid, TDP-43) forming rimmed vacuoles
• Predominant involvement of quadriceps and finger flexors in patients >50 years
Clinically, IBM is slowly progressive, often asymmetric, and refractory to standard immunotherapy. Recognizing the mixed inflammatory/degenerative pathology explains why immunosuppression fails and why management centers on preserving function.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Supportive treatment (physical therapy, occupational therapy, assistive devices) is the cornerstone of IBM management. Multiple randomized trials and guidelines have demonstrated:
• AAN 2016 Practice Guideline on Inflammatory Myopathies (Level B evidence) found no durable benefit of corticosteroids, IVIG, or immunosuppressants in IBM.
• ENMC 2018 International Workshop concluded that no immunomodulatory agent (including methotrexate, azathioprine, IVIG) leads to clinically meaningful improvement.
• Phase II trials of bimagrumab (2017) and arimoclomol (2018) failed primary endpoints.
Thus, the focus is on strength-preserving exercise, fall prevention, gait aids, and management of dysphagia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Steroid
– IBM shows only transient, minimal response in <10% of patients; risk of long-term steroid myopathy and metabolic complications.
– Misconception: IBM is “just another polymyositis.” Unlike polymyositis, IBM has a degenerative component.

B. IVIG
– Small open-label studies reported no consistent functional gain; high cost and adverse effects outweigh unproven benefits.
– Misconception: all inflammatory myopathies respond to IVIG; IBM’s pathophysiology includes protein aggregation resistant to immunoglobulin modulation.

D. Immunosuppressants
– Agents such as methotrexate and azathioprine have failed to show efficacy in RCTs; expose patients to added immunosuppression risks.
– Misconception: stronger immunosuppression will eventually control IBM’s inflammatory component; in reality, degeneration predominates.

Clinical Pearls

- Finger flexor and quadriceps weakness disproportionate in IBM helps distinguish from PM/DM.
• CK levels in IBM are often normal or mildly elevated (<15× ULN) versus higher elevations in other myopathies.
• Early referral to PT/OT and swallow evaluation can delay loss of ambulation and reduce aspiration risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating IBM as polymyositis with high-dose steroids, delaying appropriate supportive care.
2. Overinterpreting modest CK elevations to favor immunotherapy rather than pursuing biopsy confirmation.

1. American Academy of Neurology, 2016 Practice Guideline on Inflammatory Myopathies
• Recommendation: “Corticosteroids, IVIG, and immunosuppressants are not effective in IBM” (Level B).
2. ENMC (European Neuromuscular Centre) IBM Workshop, 2018
• Conclusion: “Supportive and rehabilitative therapies remain the only evidence-based approach.”
3. Bimagrumab Phase IIb Trial (Louie et al., Lancet Neurol 2020)
• Outcome: Failed to meet primary muscle strength endpoints (Level II evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

IBM combines:
• Autoimmune attack (CD8+ T cells recognizing MHC-I–expressing fibers)
• Degenerative protein misfolding (β-amyloid, phosphorylated tau)
The degenerative process renders immunotherapy largely ineffective.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: age >50, finger flexor/quadriceps weakness, falls.
2. Lab: CK normal/mildly elevated.
3. EMG: myopathic potentials with early recruitment.
4. Muscle biopsy: endomysial inflammation, rimmed vacuoles, congophilic inclusions.
5. Management: initiate supportive therapies immediately; avoid futile immunosuppression.

[Exam: Part 2 2024] - Limb-girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) are characterized by proximal muscle weakness affecting pelvic and shoulder girdle muscles.
• Autosomal-recessive LGMDs (e.g., calpainopathy, LGMD2A) often present in adolescence with elevated CK, positive Gower sign (using hands to “walk” up legs), and scapular winging from trapezius/serratus anterior weakness.
• Genetic inheritance patterns and age of onset help differentiate subtypes: AR forms in early teens, X-linked Duchenne in early childhood, AD facioscapulohumeral with facial involvement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Calpainopathy (LGMD2A) arises from CAPN3 mutations on chromosome 15q15.1, leading to calpain-3 protease deficiency and muscle fiber necrosis (Richard et al., Neurology 2021). Onset typically between age 8–15 years with pelvic girdle weakness progressing to scapular winging; CK levels often > 10× normal. The AR pattern and affected sister in a consanguineous family further support LGMD2A.
The 2018 AAN Practice Guideline on LGMD recommends next-generation sequencing gene panels for definitive diagnosis (Level B evidence). Muscle MRI shows selective fatty infiltration of posterior thigh muscles early in LGMD2A (Tasca et al., Neuromuscul Disord 2020).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Dysferlinopathy
• Presents later (adulthood) with distal calf weakness (Miyoshi phenotype) or proximal limb symptoms; scapular winging less prominent.
• Onset usually > 15 years; CK mildly lower than in calpainopathy.

C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• X-linked recessive affecting only boys; onset 3–5 years with calf pseudohypertrophy; rapid progression to loss of ambulation by early teens.

D. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy
• Autosomal dominant; facial weakness (inability to whistle), asymmetric scapular winging, onset in teens/adulthood; trunk and humeral involvement more than pelvic girdle.

• Muscle MRI can guide which LGMD subtype to genetically test; posterior thigh involvement is classic in calpainopathy.
• Always consider inheritance pattern: AR diseases can affect multiple siblings of either sex in consanguineous families.

1. Assuming all Gower sign–positive patients have Duchenne MD—ignores inheritance and age of onset.
2. Overlooking scapular winging in FSHD is typically asymmetric with facial weakness, not pure pelvic girdle.

• AAN Practice Guideline on LGMD (American Academy of Neurology, 2018): recommends gene panel testing as first-line diagnostic tool in suspected LGMD (Level B).
• ENMC Consensus Statement on LGMD (European Neuromuscular Centre, 2020): outlines standardized approach including clinical screening, CK measurement, muscle imaging, then targeted genetic testing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Calpain-3 is a muscle-specific calcium-activated protease involved in sarcomeric remodeling. CAPN3 mutations lead to defective proteostasis, zonal necrosis, and fatty replacement of muscle fibers, predominantly in pelvic and shoulder girdle.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: proximal weakness, Gower sign, scapular winging.
2. Serum CK: marked elevation (> 10× normal).
3. EMG: myopathic pattern.
4. Muscle MRI: pattern of fatty infiltration.
5. Genetic testing: LGMD gene panel with CAPN3 analysis.
