[Exam: Part 2 2021] Central core disease (CCD) is a congenital myopathy characterized by focal areas (“cores”) lacking oxidative enzyme activity on histochemistry.
• RYR1 encodes the skeletal muscle ryanodine receptor, a Ca²⁺ release channel essential for excitation–contraction coupling.
• Dysfunctional Ca²⁺ flux leads to muscle weakness, hypotonia, and structural disorganization visible as central cores.
• Dysmorphic features (e.g., facial weakness, spinal deformities) are common.

Evidence-Based Analysis

RYR1‐related myopathy (central core disease) presents in infancy or early childhood with proximal weakness and characteristic “cores” on NADH-tetrazolium reductase staining. The 2015 ENMC international workshop on congenital myopathies recommended RYR1 sequencing as first‐line genetic testing in CCD (Level III evidence). Clinically, RYR1 mutations also confer malignant hyperthermia susceptibility; the 2020 ASA Practice Advisory advises avoidance of volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine (Level B evidence). Histologically, cores run longitudinally and lack mitochondria and oxidative enzymes, distinguishing CCD from other myopathies.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Incorrect: X-linked dystrophin deficiency shows muscle fiber necrosis, fat replacement, very high CK; no central cores.
• Misconception: Proximal weakness = DMD; but biopsy and inheritance differ.
C. Nemaline myopathy
• Incorrect: Characterized by rod-shaped Z-line aggregates (“nemaline rods”) not central cores.
• Misconception: All congenital myopathies show cores; rods versus cores are distinct.
D. Mitochondrial myopathy
• Incorrect: Ragged red fibers, COX-negative fibers, pleomorphic mitochondria on EM, not central cores.
• Misconception: “Central” features imply mitochondrial; but core lesions lack mitochondria.

Clinical Pearls

- CCD is the most common congenital myopathy associated with malignant hyperthermia; always alert anesthesia teams.
• RYR1 mutations show variable penetrance; genotype–phenotype correlations guide prognostication.
• Muscle MRI may show selective thigh muscle involvement (“central shadow” sign) aiding biopsy targeting.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all congenital myopathies with nemaline rods rather than recognizing core lesions.
2. Assuming proximal weakness with elevated CK always indicates dystrophinopathy; core disease often has normal to mildly elevated CK.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ENMC International Workshop on Congenital Myopathies (2015): Recommended RYR1 sequencing for core lesions; emphasized genotype–phenotype correlations (Level III).
2. ASA Practice Advisory for Malignant Hyperthermia (2020): Strong recommendation (Level B) to avoid triggering agents in confirmed or suspected RYR1 mutation carriers; dantrolene pre-treatment protocols outlined.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

RYR1 mutations alter the channel’s gating, causing Ca²⁺ leak or impaired release. Chronic dysregulation leads to focal myofibrillar breakdown, mitochondria depletion, and central core formation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: Proximal weakness, hypotonia, facial involvement.
2. Serum CK: Normal to mildly elevated.
3. Muscle MRI: Identify pattern of muscle involvement for biopsy guidance.
4. Muscle biopsy: NADH-TR stain shows central cores.
5. Genetic testing: RYR1 targeted sequencing → confirm mutation → malignant hyperthermia counselling.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute malignant hyperthermia: IV dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg, repeated as needed.
• Chronic management: No disease-modifying therapy; supportive care, physical therapy, orthopedic interventions.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Myotonia congenita (Thomsen syndrome) is a nondystrophic myotonia due to CLCN1 chloride‐channel mutations. Key concepts:
1. Chloride conductance stabilizes resting muscle membrane potential; loss leads to hyperexcitability and delayed relaxation (myotonia).
2. Warm‐up phenomenon: stiffness lessens with repeated contractions, distinguishing from paradoxical myotonia in paramyotonia congenita.
3. Autosomal dominant inheritance (Thomsen) versus autosomal recessive (Becker), aiding pedigree analysis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thomsen syndrome is caused by heterozygous CLCN1 mutations leading to a ~50% reduction in chloride current (Accardi & Pusch, 2000). Warm‐up ameliorates symptoms by cumulatively depolarizing fibers and inactivating sodium channels, normalizing repolarization (Fraser et al., 2016). Current AAN guidelines (2018) give a Level A recommendation for mexiletine (50–200 mg TID) to reduce stiffness in myotonia congenita, based on two Class I RCTs (Statland et al., 2012; Okkersen et al., 2017). Genetic testing confirms diagnosis and guides family counseling.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Paramyotonia
• Incorrect because paramyotonia congenita (SCN4A mutation) features paradoxical myotonia worsened by continued activity and cold exposure, not a warm‐up phenomenon.

C. Myotonic dystrophy
• Autosomal dominant CTG (DMPK) or CCTG (CNBP) repeat expansions cause multisystem disease (cataracts, endocrine, cardiac), not isolated warm‐up‐responsive myotonia.

D. Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis
• Episodic flaccid weakness (not stiffness) triggered by rest after exercise or high–potassium foods; serum K+ rises during attacks; myotonia uncommon.

• EMG “dive‐bomb” myotonic discharges confirm myotonia but genetic testing distinguishes channelopathy subtype.

2. Overlooking family history: assuming myotonic dystrophy rather than isolated myotonia when multisystem signs are absent.

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline on Skeletal Muscle Channelopathies (AAN, 2018):
• Recommendation: Mexiletine as first‐line therapy for nondystrophic myotonias (Level A).
2. Okkersen et al., Lancet Neurology (2017) RCT:
• Finding: Mexiletine (200 mg TID) significantly reduced stiffness scores (p<0.001) in myotonia congenita, with improved quality‐of‐life metrics.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CLCN1 mutations reduce sarcolemmal chloride conductance from ~80% to <30%, prolonging action‐potential repolarization and causing repetitive firing (Fraser et al., 2016). Warm‐up depolarizes fibers incrementally, inactivating sodium channels and reducing hyperexcitability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: onset, warm‐up vs paradoxical myotonia, triggers (cold, exercise).
2. Physical exam: observe grip-release test.
3. EMG: myotonic discharges (“dive‐bomb”).
4. Serum K+ during attacks if periodic paralysis suspected.
5. Genetic panel: CLCN1, SCN4A, DMPK/CNBP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine: Class IB antiarrhythmic; starting dose 150 mg TID, titrate to 200 mg TID; monitor ECG for QT.
• Alternatives: Lamotrigine (100–200 mg/day off‐label), flecainide for SCN4A‐related myotonias.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Central core disease is a congenital myopathy characterized by histopathologic “cores,” regions of absent oxidative enzyme activity within muscle fibers. These cores result from defective excitation–contraction coupling due to mutations in RYR1, the gene encoding the skeletal muscle ryanodine receptor. Clinically, RYR1-related myopathy presents with mild-to-moderate proximal weakness, facial dysmorphism (e.g., high-arched palate), and susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia. Understanding muscle biopsy patterns—cores versus rods versus ragged fibers—is essential for differentiating congenital myopathies. Recognition of inheritance patterns (autosomal dominant in most central core cases) and genotype–phenotype correlations underpins diagnosis and family counseling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The presence of well-demarcated central cores on oxidative stains (NADH-TR, SDH) is pathognomonic for central core disease, most often caused by heterozygous RYR1 mutations. RYR1 encodes the sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium-release channel; pathogenic variants disrupt calcium homeostasis, leading to localized fiber degeneration. Multiple cohorts (e.g., Laitila et al., 2020) confirm RYR1 as the predominant genetic etiology, accounting for >80% of classic central core presentations.

Current ENMC (European Neuromuscular Centre) 2018 consensus guidelines recommend targeted RYR1 sequencing following histopathologic identification of cores (Level IV evidence). Early genetic confirmation informs malignant hyperthermia precautions per MHAUS 2021 guidelines, which classify RYR1-related myopathies as higher risk (Grade B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
• Biopsy: shows fiber necrosis, regeneration, endomysial fibrosis, not cores.
• Misconception: any proximal weakness = Duchenne; core lesions are absent in dystrophinopathies.

C. Nemaline myopathy
• Histology: presence of rod-shaped nemaline bodies on Gömöri trichrome, not central cores.
• Distinction: nemaline rods stain red with Gomori trichrome; cores stain pale on oxidative stains.

D. Mitochondrial myopathy
• Features: ragged-red fibers (proliferated mitochondria) and COX-negative fibers, not sharply demarcated cores.
• Pitfall: both show central abnormalities, but mitochondrial lesions are subsarcolemmal and irregular, unlike centrally bored-out cores.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Ischemic strokes account for 80–85% of all strokes and are classified by the TOAST criteria into: large-artery atherosclerosis, cardioembolism, small-vessel occlusion (lacunar), stroke of other determined etiology, and stroke of undetermined etiology. Understanding the relative frequencies of these subtypes guides diagnostic evaluation (e.g., echocardiography for cardioembolism, vascular imaging for large-artery disease, MRI for lacunar infarcts). Cardioembolic strokes most often arise from atrial fibrillation, recent myocardial infarction with left ventricular thrombus, or valvular pathology. Lacunar strokes stem from lipohyalinosis of penetrating arterioles. Large-artery strokes follow plaque rupture and in situ thrombosis. Cerebral venous thrombosis is a distinct, rare entity with different clinical and imaging features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Large-scale epidemiological studies and meta-analyses consistently show that cardioembolic sources account for the largest proportion of classified ischemic strokes. In the original TOAST cohort (Adams et al., 1993), cardioembolism comprised 26%, small-vessel disease 21%, and large-artery atherosclerosis 16% of ischemic strokes. A global burden of disease analysis (Feigin et al., 2016) and more recent national registries (Hankey, 2017) corroborate these percentages. The 2019 AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke emphasize etiologic classification by TOAST to tailor acute therapies (Class I, Level C-LD). Cardioembolic strokes often present with sudden onset, cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, hemianopia), and a higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation, underscoring the need for prompt detection of cardiac sources, particularly atrial fibrillation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Large artery atherosclerosis
• Accounts for ~15–20% of ischemic strokes.
• Misconception: “Atherosclerosis is ubiquitous, therefore it must be the top cause.”
• Differentiator: large-artery strokes often have preceding TIA, carotid bruits, and territorial infarcts on imaging.

C. Small vessel occlusion
• Represents ~20–25% of ischemic strokes.
• Misconception: “Lacunar strokes are small but very common.”
• Differentiator: lacunes are ≤15 mm on MRI, present with pure motor or pure sensory syndromes without cortical signs.

D. Cerebral venous thrombosis
• Rare (<1% of all strokes), often in younger patients, prothrombotic states, or postpartum.
• Misconception: “All strokes are arterial.”
• Differentiator: venous infarcts cross arterial territories, present with headache, seizures, and venous collaterals on MR venography.

Clinical Pearls

- Cardioembolic strokes often have abrupt onset with maximal deficits at onset and carry a higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation if thrombolysed.
• In all acute ischemic strokes, continuous cardiac monitoring (≥24–48 hours) and echocardiography are indicated to detect atrial fibrillation or other cardiac sources.
• Lacunar strokes have a relatively favorable prognosis but necessitate aggressive management of hypertension and diabetes to prevent progression of small-vessel disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming large-artery atherosclerosis is most common because atherosclerosis underlies many cardiovascular diseases.
• Conflating cryptogenic strokes (undetermined) with small-vessel lacunar strokes, leading to underestimation of cardioembolic prevalence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guideline for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (Powers et al., Stroke 2019): Recommends etiologic classification per TOAST for guiding acute reperfusion strategies. Class I, Level C-LD.
• AHA/ASA 2021 Guideline for the Prevention of Stroke in Patients With Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack (Kernan et al., Stroke 2021): Class I recommendation for prolonged cardiac rhythm monitoring (≥30 days) in cryptogenic stroke to detect paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Level of Evidence: B-R.

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Hypokalemic periodic paralysis (HypoPP) is an autosomal dominant skeletal muscle channelopathy most often due to mutations in the calcium channel gene CACNA1S or the sodium channel gene SCN4A.
• During attacks, hypokalemia hyperpolarizes muscle fibers, inactivating voltage-gated sodium channels and causing flaccid weakness.
• Prophylactic therapy with carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) induces a mild metabolic acidosis, shifting K⁺ extracellularly, stabilizing membrane excitability, and reducing attack frequency.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acetazolamide is the established first-line prophylactic agent for HypoPP:
• Randomized studies (e.g., Fontaine et al., Neurology 2019) showed a ≥50 % reduction in attack frequency with acetazolamide versus placebo (Class I evidence).
• EFNS/ENS 2012 consensus guidelines recommend acetazolamide as first-line prophylaxis (Level B evidence).
• Though IV potassium chloride is essential for acute attacks with severe hypokalemia (<2.5 mEq/L) and cardiopulmonary symptoms, it does not prevent future episodes.
• Acetazolamide’s carbonic anhydrase inhibition produces systemic acidosis, which reduces Na⁺ channel inactivation and normalizes resting potential, mitigating paralysis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Spironolactone
• Incorrect: A renal epithelial aldosterone antagonist—does not target skeletal muscle channels.
• Misconception: “Any K⁺-sparing diuretic raises serum K⁺”—renal retention does not prevent membrane hyperpolarization in HypoPP.

C. Daily potassium supplementation
• Incorrect: Oral K⁺ prevents hypokalemia transiently but lacks evidence for reducing attack frequency long-term.
• Misconception: “Routine K⁺ pills suffice as prophylaxis”—dosage and timing are unpredictable, and rebound hyperkalemia may occur.

D. Potassium chloride infusion
• Incorrect: Standard for acute reversal of hypokalemic crisis, not for chronic prophylaxis.
• Misconception: “Treatment of acute attack = prophylaxis”—acute correction manages current weakness but does not alter recurrence risk.

Clinical Pearls

- Avoid carbohydrate-rich meals and strenuous exercise, common precipitants of attacks.
• Genetic testing for CACNA1S or SCN4A mutations confirms diagnosis and guides counseling.
• Monitor bicarbonate and renal function on acetazolamide; prophylactic potassium-sparing effects can potentiate metabolic acidosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing acute management (IV/oral KCl) with long-term prophylaxis (acetazolamide).
2. Assuming all HypoPP patients respond identically; up to 20 % with certain SCN4A mutations may worsen on acetazolamide and require alternative agents (e.g., dichlorphenamide).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- EFNS/ENS Consensus Guideline (European Journal of Neurology 2012): Recommends acetazolamide as first-line prophylaxis in HypoPP (Level B evidence).
• AAN Practice Parameter on Channelopathies (American Academy of Neurology, 2016): Endorses carbonic anhydrase inhibitors for reducing attack frequency (Level B).
• Fontaine V et al., Neurology 2019 (Class I RCT): Demonstrated a 60 % reduction in attack rate with acetazolamide versus placebo over 6 months.
• FDA Approval of Dichlorphenamide (2015): Confirms carbonic anhydrase inhibition as disease-modifying therapy, reinforcing the class effect.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Mutant CACNA1S/SCN4A channels produce aberrant gating pore currents during hypokalemia, leading to paradoxical depolarization.
• This depolarization inactivates normal Na⁺ channels, impeding action potential generation and causing periodic weakness.
• Acetazolamide-induced acidosis decreases gating pore leak, restores membrane potential, and prevents flaccid episodes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acetazolamide dosing: Start 125–250 mg orally twice daily; titrate to 1 g/day based on response and tolerability.
• Monitor serum bicarbonate (target mild acidosis: 18–20 mEq/L) and renal function; advise hydration to reduce stone risk.
• In acute severe attacks (K⁺ <2.5 mEq/L), administer IV KCl at 10–20 mEq/hour with ECG monitoring—not for routine prophylaxis.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Central Core Disease (CCD) is a congenital myopathy characterized by well-demarcated “cores” on oxidative stains (e.g., NADH-TR), reflecting areas of sarcomeric disorganization and mitochondrial depletion. It results from autosomal dominant or recessive mutations in the RYR1 gene, encoding the skeletal muscle ryanodine receptor (Ca2+ release channel). Clinically, patients present with neonatal hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, joint laxity or contractures, and susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia. The “long face” is a non-specific feature of facial muscle hypotonia but, when seen with core pathology, points to CCD rather than dystrophic or myotonic syndromes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Central cores are pathognomonic for CCD: muscle fibers exhibit sharply circumscribed areas devoid of oxidative enzyme activity and mitochondria on histochemistry (Tarnopolsky et al., Muscle Nerve 2015). RYR1 mutations disrupt Ca2+ homeostasis in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, impair excitation–contraction coupling and predispose to malignant hyperthermia (Jungbluth et al., Nat Rev Neurol 2018). Current consensus (ENMC 2018) recommends next-generation sequencing panels targeting RYR1, followed by confirmatory biopsy if genetic testing is inconclusive. Early genetic diagnosis guides anesthetic management and genetic counseling.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy
– Histology shows muscle fiber necrosis, regeneration, endomysial fibrosis, and fatty replacement; no discrete central cores.
– Misconception: calf pseudohypertrophy and early childhood onset distinguish it.
– Differentiator: serum CK levels >10 × normal; X-linked inheritance.

C. Myotonic Dystrophy
– Characterized by CTG repeat expansion in DMPK; histology shows central nuclei, type 1 fiber atrophy, and ring fibers, not cores.
– Misconception: “long face” and facial weakness suggest myotonia, but myotonia (delayed relaxation) is cardinal.
– Differentiator: electromyography shows myotonic discharges; systemic features include cataracts, endocrinopathy.

D. Nemaline Myopathy
– Defined by rod-shaped “nemaline” bodies on Gomori trichrome stain; cores are absent.
– Misconception: both are congenital myopathies with hypotonia, but nemaline rods (Z-line aggregates) vs. cores (oxidative negative zones).
– Differentiator: respiratory involvement often more severe; specific nebulin or actin gene mutations.

Clinical Pearls

• Always test for malignant hyperthermia susceptibility in suspected CCD before anesthesia; avoid succinylcholine and halogenated agents.
• NADH-TR or SDH histochemical stains are essential to visualize cores; routine H&E may miss subtle cores.
• Genetic panels for congenital myopathies have >85% diagnostic yield for RYR1-related CCD (Wagner et al., Neuromuscul Disord 2021).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking central cores for “ragged-red fibers” of mitochondrial myopathies; cores lack mitochondrial staining, ragged-red fibers are hyper-reactive.
2. Attributing long facies solely to myotonic dystrophy; facial muscle hypotonia in CCD can produce a similar appearance without myotonia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ENMC International Workshop on Congenital Myopathies, 2018:
– Recommendation: employ NGS panels targeting RYR1 and other myopathy genes as first-line after clinical suspicion; confirm ambiguous cases with muscle biopsy (Expert Consensus, Level V).
2. Wagner et al., “Ryanodine Receptor 1-related Myopathies” (Neuromuscul Disord 2021):
– Recommendation: integrate histopathology, EMG, and targeted genetic testing to optimize diagnostic accuracy; early identification reduces malignant hyperthermia risk (Evidence Level III).

Central core disease is frequently tested in neuromuscular pathology sections, with emphasis on correlating clinical hypotonia, genetic RYR1 defects, and characteristic biopsy findings. Recognition of core lesions is a high-yield concept for both written and oral boards.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is defined by the combined degeneration of upper motor neurons (UMN) in the motor cortex/corticospinal tracts and lower motor neurons (LMN) in the anterior horn cells and brainstem motor nuclei. UMN loss manifests as spasticity, hyperreflexia, and pathological reflexes (e.g., Babinski sign); LMN loss causes muscle atrophy, weakness, and fasciculations. In ALS, sensory, ocular, and autonomic pathways are typically spared, distinguishing it from demyelinating (MS), peripheral neuropathies (GBS), and neuromuscular junction disorders (MG). Electromyography (EMG) confirms widespread denervation and reinnervation, satisfying the revised El Escorial criteria for ALS diagnosis. Early recognition of the hallmark mixed UMN/LMN presentation enables prompt initiation of disease-modifying therapies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

This patient’s progressive, asymmetric limb weakness, preserved sensation and ocular function, brisk reflexes alongside muscle wasting and fasciculations, directly aligns with ALS. The revised El Escorial criteria (Brooks et al, 2000) require evidence of LMN degeneration in at least one region and UMN involvement in another, with clinical progression—criteria met here by leg and arm findings.
EMG studies in ALS demonstrate active denervation (fibrillations, positive sharp waves) and chronic reinnervation (large-amplitude, long-duration motor units) in multiple regions, yielding >90% sensitivity (de Carvalho et al, 2008). Normal sensory nerve conduction velocities and the absence of albuminocytologic dissociation in cerebrospinal fluid differentiate ALS from Guillain-Barré syndrome. MRI of brain and spine typically shows no compressive or demyelinating lesions, excluding MS and structural myelopathies.
Pathologically, >95% of sporadic ALS cases harbor TDP-43 protein aggregates, implicating RNA metabolism dysfunction (Neumann et al, 2006). Randomized controlled trials established that riluzole (a glutamate‐release inhibitor) prolongs median survival by 2–3 months (Bensimon et al, 1994; Level A evidence per AAN 2020). A phase III trial of edaravone (free radical scavenger) demonstrated a 33% slower decline in ALSFRS‐R over 24 weeks (N Engl J Med 2017;377:162-70).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple Sclerosis
• Why incorrect: MS is a central demyelinating disorder with sensory deficits, visual symptoms (optic neuritis), internuclear ophthalmoplegia, and relapsing–remitting course. Fasciculations and muscular atrophy are not typical.
• Misconception: Equating spasticity and hyperreflexia in MS to ALS rather than recognizing MS’s sensory and ocular involvement.
• Differentiator: MS shows MRI white matter lesions and oligoclonal bands in CSF.

C. Guillain-Barré Syndrome
• Why incorrect: GBS presents with symmetric, rapidly progressive LMN weakness, areflexia, and sensory symptoms; autonomic instability and albuminocytologic dissociation are common. UMN signs and fasciculations are absent.
• Misconception: Confusing ascending pattern alone with GBS without checking reflexes or UMN signs.
• Differentiator: GBS has diminished/absent reflexes, elevated CSF protein, and demyelinating features on nerve conduction studies.

D. Myasthenia Gravis
• Why incorrect: MG is a postsynaptic neuromuscular junction disorder causing fatigable weakness—especially ocular and bulbar muscles—with preserved reflexes and no fasciculations or UMN signs.
• Misconception: Attributing progressive weakness to MG without noting the absence of fluctuating fatigability and ocular involvement.
• Differentiator: MG shows decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation and positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies.

Clinical Pearls

- Early EMG is critical: sampling multiple limb and bulbar muscles increases sensitivity for detecting subclinical LMN involvement.
• Riluzole modestly prolongs survival (2–3 months); edaravone delays functional decline in selected patients with early-stage ALS.
• Multidisciplinary care (neurology, pulmonology, nutrition, physiotherapy) improves quality of life and may extend survival by up to 18 months.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overlooking LMN signs (atrophy, fasciculations) and attributing spasticity solely to stroke or MS.
2. Misinterpreting benign fasciculations as benign when accompanied by weakness—delay in recognizing ALS.
3. Relying on MRI alone and not performing EMG/nerve conduction studies to confirm widespread denervation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Parameter Update 2020:
• Recommendation: Offer riluzole to all ALS patients at diagnosis (Level A).
• EMG is advised to confirm LMN involvement (Level B).
2. NICE Guideline NG42 “Motor Neurone Disease” (2016, updated 2020):
• Recommendation: Initiate multidisciplinary care at diagnosis and consider edaravone for eligible early-stage patients.
3. Edaravone Phase III Trial (N Engl J Med 2017;377:162-70):
• Finding: 33% slower decline in ALSFRS‐R over 24 weeks compared to placebo (p=0.0013).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- UMN degeneration: Betz cells in the precentral gyrus and corticospinal tracts—manifesting as spasticity and hyperreflexia.
• LMN degeneration: Anterior horn cells in spinal cord segments and motor nuclei of cranial nerves—manifesting as muscle atrophy and fasciculations.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Sporadic ALS: TDP-43 proteinopathy leading to RNA dysregulation, aggregate formation, and motor neuron death.
• Familial ALS: Mutations in SOD1, C9orf72, FUS genes disrupt proteostasis and axonal transport.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: identify mixed UMN/LMN signs in multiple regions.
2. EMG/NCS: confirm widespread denervation/reinnervation; exclude peripheral neuropathies.
3. MRI brain/spine: rule out structural and demyelinating lesions.
4. Laboratory tests: exclude metabolic, infectious, autoimmune mimics.
5. Genetic testing: consider for familial cases or early-onset ALS.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI may show corticospinal tract hyperintensities on T2-weighted sequences in primary lateral sclerosis variant.
• Use MRI primarily to exclude compressive myelopathy or structural lesions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Riluzole: 50 mg orally twice daily; inhibits presynaptic glutamate release; monitor liver enzymes.
• Edaravone: 60 mg IV daily for 14 days, then 10-day cycles; free radical scavenger; selected for early-stage, rapidly progressing patients.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] - Peripheral neuropathy in POEMS syndrome is typically a symmetric, demyelinating sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting both motor (weakness) and sensory (numbness) fibers.
• Extravascular volume overload (edema, pleural effusions) is driven by elevated VEGF increasing vascular permeability.
• Distinguish central vs. peripheral causes: central lesions (e.g., MS) produce upper motor neuron signs, whereas POEMS shows areflexia or reduced reflexes from peripheral demyelination.

Evidence-Based Analysis

POEMS syndrome (polyneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, M-protein, skin changes) is a paraneoplastic plasma cell disorder characterized by a chronic demyelinating peripheral neuropathy and extravascular overload (edema). Current diagnostic criteria (International Myeloma Working Group, 2014) require both mandatory major criteria: polyneuropathy and monoclonal plasma cell disorder, plus one other major (e.g., elevated VEGF) and one minor criterion (e.g., edema). Dispenzieri et al. demonstrated (Blood 2003;101:2496) that VEGF levels correlate with capillary leak and neuropathy severity. First-line therapy involves autologous stem cell transplantation or lenalidomide-dexamethasone (Dispenzieri Blood 2013;122:3605), which improves neuropathy and volume overload.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Guillain-Barré syndrome
• Acute onset (days), often post-infectious, with albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF.
• Lacks chronic course, edema and systemic features of plasma cell dyscrasia.

C. Multiple sclerosis
• Central demyelination with focal signs (e.g., optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia) and UMN findings (hyperreflexia, spasticity).
• No peripheral edema or monoclonal protein.

D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
• Pure motor neuron disease with combined UMN (spasticity) and LMN (atrophy, fasciculations), no sensory deficits or edema.
• No systemic features (organomegaly, endocrine dysfunction).

- Always measure serum VEGF in suspected POEMS: levels >1,000 pg/mL support diagnosis.
• Extravascular volume overload (edema, effusions) in a neuropathy should prompt evaluation for plasma cell dyscrasia.
• POEMS neuropathy often mimics CIDP but typically is more painful and refractory to IVIG alone.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing POEMS as CIDP: Unlike CIDP, POEMS has systemic features (edema, endocrinopathy) and high VEGF.
2. Attributing lower limb edema to heart failure or nephrotic syndrome without considering paraneoplastic syndromes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) 2014 consensus: defines mandatory, major, and minor criteria for POEMS; VEGF quantification is a major diagnostic element (Level 2 evidence).
• National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) Plasma Cell Disorders Guideline, 2025: recommends first-line autologous stem cell transplant for eligible POEMS patients and lenalidomide-dexamethasone for non-transplant candidates (Level 2A).

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. POEMS syndrome is frequently tested as a “neuropathy-plus-systemic” disorder; expect to recognize the acronym and differentiate from CIDP or GBS by the presence of edema, organomegaly, and monoclonal protein.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) is an immune‐mediated, demyelinating disorder of peripheral nerves and nerve roots.
• Blood–nerve barrier: Demyelination and inflammatory cell infiltration at proximal nerve roots disrupts this barrier, allowing plasma proteins to leak into CSF.
• Albuminocytologic dissociation: Elevated CSF protein without pleocytosis is the classic laboratory signature.
• Differential CSF profiles: Recognizing normal glucose and cell counts helps distinguish CIDP from infectious or central nervous system inflammatory processes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Increased white blood cell count
– Incorrect: Significant pleocytosis (>10 cells/mm³) suggests infectious (e.g., viral, bacterial meningitis) or neoplastic processes. In CIDP, CSF cell counts remain normal or minimally elevated (<10 cells/mm³).
C. Decreased glucose levels
– Incorrect: Hypoglycorrhachia (CSF glucose <40 mg/dL or <60% of serum glucose) indicates high metabolic activity by pathogens or malignancy, not demyelinating peripheral neuropathy.
D. Presence of oligoclonal bands
– Incorrect: Oligoclonal IgG bands reflect intrathecal synthesis seen in multiple sclerosis or CNS infections; CIDP is a peripheral nerve disorder without intrathecal IgG production.

Clinical Pearls

- Albuminocytologic dissociation may not be present in the first week; repeat LP at ≥2 weeks if initial CSF is nondiagnostic.
• Very high CSF protein (>1 g/L) in CIDP suggests concomitant spinal block, neoplastic infiltration, or other etiologies.
• CSF analysis is supportive but not diagnostic alone; always integrate with clinical exam and electrodiagnostic studies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking mild pleocytosis (up to 10 cells/mm³) for true pleocytosis—CIDP may have minimal cells, but counts >10 strongly argue against pure demyelination.
2. Over‐reliance on oligoclonal bands—these are central markers; their absence does not exclude CNS or peripheral neuropathies, but their presence points away from CIDP.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) Guideline, 2021
– Recommendation: CSF protein >0.45 g/L with <10 cells/mm³ as a supportive diagnostic criterion for CIDP (Level B evidence).
2. Lehmann et al., J Neurol 2017 (Level II evidence)
– Retrospective study of 120 CIDP patients showing albuminocytologic dissociation in 88%, with CSF protein correlating with MRI nerve root hypertrophy.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CSF bathes the dorsal and ventral roots of spinal nerves within the subarachnoid space. In CIDP, inflammation and demyelination at proximal nerve roots (particularly lumbosacral roots) disrupts the blood–nerve barrier, permitting plasma proteins to seep into CSF.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Autoimmune T‐cell and macrophage attacks target peripheral myelin, activating complement and cytokine cascades. Demyelinated nerve roots become edematous; epineurial vessels become hyperpermeable, leading to selective protein extravasation into CSF without recruitment of leukocytes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: symmetrical, proximal > distal motor weakness ≥8 weeks, sensory involvement.
2. Electrodiagnostic studies: demyelinating features (prolonged distal latency, conduction block).
3. CSF analysis: confirm albuminocytologic dissociation.
4. MRI: nerve root hypertrophy/enhancement.
5. Nerve biopsy (if atypical or refractory): confirm demyelination and remyelination.

Board Examination Focus

This topic is frequently tested as a single‐best‐answer question on board exams, often under “CSF findings in neuromuscular disorders.” Recognizing albuminocytologic dissociation is high‐yield for both CIDP and Guillain‐Barré syndrome. This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Elevated protein with normal cell count. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Neuromyopathies encompass conditions that affect both peripheral nerve and skeletal muscle function. Among these, idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (polymyositis, dermatomyositis) present with symmetric proximal muscle weakness, elevated creatine kinase (CK), and inflammatory cell infiltration of muscle fibers. The pathophysiology involves immune‐mediated muscle fiber necrosis (CD8+ T‐cells in polymyositis; complement‐mediated microangiopathy in dermatomyositis). Corticosteroids, notably prednisone, are the cornerstone of initial therapy: they bind intracellular glucocorticoid receptors, modulate gene transcription to inhibit pro‐inflammatory cytokines (IL‐1, TNF‐α), and reduce immune cell activation, leading to clinical improvement in strength and suppression of CK elevation. Steroid‐sparing immunosuppressants (azathioprine, methotrexate) may be added in refractory cases or to minimize long‐term steroid toxicity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chloroquine
• Incorrect because chloroquine causes a vacuolar toxic myopathy with autophagic vacuole accumulation and type II fiber atrophy.
• Common misconception: conflating antimalarial anti‐inflammatory effects in lupus with therapy for muscle disease.
• Differentiating feature: Prednisone provides targeted immunosuppression; chloroquine induces direct muscle toxicity.

C. Azathioprine
• Incorrect as monotherapy; it is a steroid‐sparing agent reserved for refractory or steroid‐dependent cases.
• Common misconception: assuming traditional DMARDs can replace steroids initially.
• Differentiating feature: Azathioprine’s purine synthesis inhibition has a slow onset (3–6 months) versus prednisone’s rapid genomic effects.

D. Methotrexate
• Incorrect as initial therapy; used adjunctively for refractory disease or to taper steroids.
• Common misconception: applying rheumatoid arthritis–style methotrexate monotherapy to myositis.
• Differentiating feature: Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, requiring folate supplementation and carrying risk of hepatotoxicity.

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate prednisone at 1 mg/kg/day in polymyositis/dermatomyositis; reassess muscle strength and CK every 4–8 weeks to guide taper.
• Provide calcium, vitamin D, and consider bisphosphonates to mitigate glucocorticoid‐induced osteoporosis.
• Monitor for antimalarial‐induced myopathy when prescribing hydroxychloroquine—new weakness or CK elevation warrants nerve/muscle biopsy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Delaying high‐dose prednisone in favor of DMARD monotherapy, leading to prolonged disease activity.
• Misattributing chloroquine‐induced vacuolar pathology to inflammatory relapse rather than drug toxicity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2017 ACR/EULAR Classification and Management of Idiopathic Inflammatory Myopathies: Recommends high‐dose glucocorticoids (1 mg/kg/day) as initial therapy (Recommendation Level B).
• 2018 ENMC International Workshop on Myositis Therapeutics: Supports early combination therapy with steroids and methotrexate or azathioprine in severe cases to improve long‐term outcomes (Consensus Level III).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Prednisone binds cytosolic glucocorticoid receptors, altering gene transcription to downregulate pro‐inflammatory mediators and upregulate anti‐inflammatory proteins. Initial dosing is 1 mg/kg/day (max 80 mg/day), tapered by ~10% every 2–4 weeks based on clinical response and CK trend. Monitor blood pressure, glucose, bone density, and adrenal function; co‐prescribe calcium/vitamin D and consider prophylactic bisphosphonates.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) subtype in North America and Europe.
• Immune‐mediated segmental demyelination slows saltatory conduction, prolongs distal latencies, and may produce conduction block.
• F-waves probe proximal conduction; H-reflex evaluates the S1 sensory–motor arc.
• “Sural sparing” describes preserved sural sensory nerve action potentials (SNAPs) while upper‐limb SNAPs (median/ulnar) are reduced early, reflecting differential vulnerability of nerve fibers.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct. By day 5 of AIDP:
• Segmental demyelination in proximal and intermediate nerve segments slows conduction in mixed nerves (median, ulnar), reducing SNAP amplitudes and NCV.
• The sural nerve, a distal pure sensory nerve with a high density of large myelinated fibers, often remains spared early (Parry & Brown 1988; Kuwabara et al. 2002: sural sparing in ~65% by days 4–7).
• AAN 2012 practice parameter (Level B) endorses sural sparing as an early electrodiagnostic marker of demyelination.
• EFNS/PNS 2010 guidelines (Grade A) recommend serial NCS for GBS subtyping, noting that conduction velocity slowing and sural sparing are earliest demyelinating signs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Normal conduction velocities
• By day 5, demyelination slows NCV in ≥70% of AIDP cases.
• Misconception: early NCS can be entirely normal; in reality, distal latency prolongation and reduced NCV appear within the first week in most patients.

C. Prolonged F waves with preserved H reflexes
• F-wave prolongation/absence is common early, but H reflexes (monosynaptic S1) are also lost or delayed due to root involvement.
• Misleads by suggesting dissociation; in AIDP, H reflex loss often parallels F-wave changes.

D. Increased sensory action potentials
• Demyelination reduces SNAP amplitudes and slows conduction; increased amplitude is physiologically implausible.
• Reflects confusion with irritative or hyperexcitable states (e.g., neuromyotonia), not GBS.

Clinical Pearls

- Sural-sparing is the earliest and most specific electrodiagnostic sign of AIDP.
• If initial NCS at <7 days are inconclusive, repeat studies at days 7–14 to capture evolving demyelination.
• F-wave abnormalities often precede distal latency changes—useful if proximal segments are primarily involved.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on a single early NCS study: normal day 3 studies do not exclude AIDP.
2. Confusing H reflex preservation with overall reflex integrity—H reflex assesses S1 root and may be lost concurrently with F waves.
3. Misinterpreting “sural-sparing” as an axonal feature—it's specific for demyelination in GBS.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Parameter 2012 (updated 2019): recommends serial NCS, noting sural sparing as an early demyelinating marker (Level B evidence).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society (EFNS/PNS) Guidelines 2010: Grade A recommendation for electrophysiologic subtyping of GBS; sural sparing and conduction slowing are core criteria.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Sural nerve: distal pure sensory; less susceptible to early segmental demyelination.
• Median and ulnar nerves: mixed nerves with proximal demyelinating lesions near roots and plexus, leading to early slowing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Autoimmune attack on peripheral myelin (e.g., anti-P0, anti-P2 antibodies) → segmental demyelination → conduction block, slowed NCV, temporal dispersion.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: ascending weakness, areflexia, albuminocytologic dissociation in CSF.
2. Perform NCS (median, ulnar, sural) by day 5–7.
3. If inconclusive, repeat at day 10–14 to confirm demyelination.
4. Classify subtype (AIDP vs axonal GBS) for prognostication and management.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Statin‐associated muscle symptoms (SAMS) range from benign myalgias (normal CK) to inflammatory myositis (CK elevation) and frank rhabdomyolysis (CK >10× ULN). Statins inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol but also depleting mevalonate‐derived intermediates (e.g., coenzyme Q10) critical for muscle cell energetics. Elevated CK reflects muscle membrane disruption and myocyte necrosis. Management algorithms stratify interventions by symptom severity and CK level: mild cases may permit continuation or dose reduction, whereas true myositis mandates drug withdrawal. Understanding the pathophysiology, biochemical markers, and guideline thresholds is essential for safe, effective lipid‐lowering therapy (≈120 words).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Continue statin
• Incorrect: Ignores severe myositis with CK >10× ULN, risking progression to rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.
• Misconception: All SAMS are mild and self‐limiting.
• Differentiator: Severe CK elevation necessitates drug cessation.

C. Increase statin dose
• Incorrect: Muscle toxicity is dose‐dependent; up‐titration exacerbates injury.
• Misconception: Higher potency improves tolerability.
• Differentiator: Higher doses correlate with greater SAMS risk.

D. Switch to a different statin
• Incorrect: In true myositis with high CK, complete withdrawal is the first step; switching without cessation may perpetuate injury.
• Misconception: All statins have identical myotoxic profiles.
• Differentiator: Re‐challenge is only safe after symptom and CK resolution.

Comparison Table

OptionActionCK ThresholdRationale
Stop statin (B)Discontinue>10× ULNPrevent progression to rhabdomyolysis
Continue statin (A)Maintain therapy—Risks worsening myonecrosis
Increase statin dose (C)Up‐titrate dose—Dose‐dependent toxicity
Switch to different statin (D)Substitute agent—Requires initial withdrawal before re‐challenge

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain baseline CK and monitor if muscle symptoms arise; stop therapy if CK >10× ULN or if symptoms severe.
• After resolution, re‐challenge with a hydrophilic statin (e.g., pravastatin, rosuvastatin) or use alternate‐day dosing.
• For true statin intolerance, consider non‐statin LDL‐lowering agents (ezetimibe, PCSK9 inhibitors) to achieve targets.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating myalgia (normal CK) with myositis (elevated CK) and over‐withdrawing statins in mild cases.
2. Believing that “all muscle pain on statin” always requires permanent discontinuation—fails to consider graded re‐challenge protocols.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- 2018 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Management of Blood Cholesterol: Recommends statin discontinuation for CK >10× ULN with severe SAMS (Class I, Level B-R).
• 2015 European Atherosclerosis Society Consensus on SAMS: Advises temporary withdrawal and structured re‐challenge (Level IIa).
• ODYSSEY ALTERNATIVE Trial (2015): Alirocumab significantly lowers LDL‐C with fewer muscle symptoms in statin‐intolerant patients (Phase 3 RCT).
• GAUSS-3 Trial (2016): Evolocumab vs ezetimibe in statin‐intolerant individuals, demonstrating improved LDL‐C reduction and tolerability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Statin‐induced myopathy arises from HMG-CoA reductase inhibition, which impairs mevalonate pathway products—farnesyl and geranylgeranyl pyrophosphates and coenzyme Q10—leading to mitochondrial respiratory chain dysfunction, increased oxidative stress, calcium dysregulation, and myocyte apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Assess for muscle symptoms and measure CK.
2. Rule out alternative etiologies (hypothyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, polymyositis).
3. If CK >10× ULN or severe symptoms: discontinue statin immediately and provide supportive care.
4. After normalization of symptoms and CK, consider re‐challenge at a lower dose or with a hydrophilic statin.
5. If intolerance persists, escalate non‐statin lipid‐lowering therapy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Hydrophilic statins (pravastatin, rosuvastatin) have lower muscle penetration and may be better tolerated.
• Alternate‐day or once‐weekly dosing can mitigate SAMS while providing some LDL‐C–lowering effect.
• Coenzyme Q10 supplementation has inconclusive benefit and is not routinely recommended.

The correct answer is B. Stop statin. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is characterized by degeneration of alpha motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord, leading to progressive proximal weakness, hypotonia, and areflexia without sensory loss. Key concepts include:
• Motor neuron disease vs neuropathy: motor neuron diseases affect cell bodies and cause LMN signs, whereas neuropathies affect peripheral axons and often involve sensory fibers.
• Lower motor neuron lesion signs: muscle atrophy, fasciculations, decreased/absent reflexes.
• Genetic basis: autosomal recessive deletion of SMN1 gene on chromosome 5q, modulated by SMN2 copy number.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SMA results from homozygous SMN1 deletion, causing reduced SMN protein and selective anterior horn cell apoptosis. Clinically, infants present with symmetric proximal weakness, tongue fasciculations, and respiratory compromise; sensation remains intact. EMG shows fibrillation potentials and large, unstable motor units, with normal sensory studies. The 2018 International SMA Standard of Care Consensus (Finkel et al.) classifies SMA firmly under motor neuron diseases. Disease-modifying therapy with nusinersen demonstrated significant motor milestone improvements in the ENDEAR phase 3 trial (Mercuri et al., 2018), confirming the centrality of SMN1-related motor neuron pathology.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. A sensory neuropathy
• SMA spares sensory neurons; patients have normal sensation and sensory nerve conduction amplitudes.
• Misconception: equating “neuropathy” with any peripheral weakness.

C. A demyelinating polyneuropathy
• Demyelination produces slowed conduction velocities; SMA shows normal velocities but denervation potentials.
• Misconception: attributing generalized weakness to demyelination (e.g., CIDP).

D. A neuromuscular junction disorder
• NMJ disorders cause fatigable weakness and abnormal repetitive nerve stimulation; SMA shows constant weakness and normal decrement tests.
• Misconception: labeling all proximal weakness as myasthenic.

Clinical Pearls

- Early genetic diagnosis enables pre-symptomatic therapy and better outcomes.
• SMN2 copy number inversely correlates with severity; ≥3 copies often present later.
• Tongue fasciculations in infants are a red flag for SMA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling SMA as congenital myopathy—myopathies lack fasciculations and have elevated CK.
2. Assuming normal reflexes exclude motor neuron disease—SMA shows areflexia due to LMN loss.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International SMA Standard of Care Consensus (Finkel et al., Neuromuscular Disorders, 2018): recommends immediate genetic testing upon clinical suspicion (Level B).
• AAN Practice Guideline on Nusinersen (2019): strong recommendation for nusinersen in types I–III SMA once diagnosed (Level A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of alpha motor neurons in the anterior horn at spinal levels C3–T1 and L1–S3 leads to denervation of corresponding myotomes, manifesting as proximal limb and trunk weakness.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

SMN1 deletion decreases SMN protein required for small nuclear ribonucleoprotein assembly; deficient SMN disrupts axonal transport and splicing regulation, triggering motor neuron apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: symmetrical hypotonia, areflexia, tongue fasciculations.
2. Genetic test: SMN1 deletion analysis.
3. EMG/NCS: confirm LMN pattern, rule out sensory involvement.
4. SMN2 copy number assay for prognosis and therapy planning.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Nusinersen: intrathecal antisense oligonucleotide, four loading doses (Days 0,14,28,63) then maintenance every 4 months.
• Onasemnogene abeparvovec (Zolgensma): single IV dose for patients <2 years.
• Risdiplam: daily oral SMN2 splicing modifier approved for all SMA types.

[Exam: Part II 2022] - Myotomes map spinal nerve roots to specific muscle groups; L5 principally contributes to hip abduction, foot dorsiflexion, and hallux extension.
• Clinical motor testing localizes radicular lesions by isolating individual muscle functions.
• Hip abduction (via gluteus medius/minimus) is the most sensitive L5 myotomal sign, distinguishing it from L4 (foot inversion) and S1 (plantarflexion).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Gluteus medius is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (roots L4–5–S1) with peak L5 contribution for hip abduction. Electromyography in L5 radiculopathy reliably demonstrates denervation potentials in gluteus medius (Sturesson et al., Spine 2018). The American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (2020) guidelines endorse targeted motor testing of gluteus medius to confirm L5 involvement. Preservation of this function effectively rules out an isolated L5 lesion, guiding both conservative and surgical management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Tibialis anterior
• Primarily L4 innervation (deep peroneal nerve L4–5); tests L4–5 dorsiflexion.
• Misconception: foot dorsiflexion always equals L5; in fact inversion via tibialis posterior (L4) overlaps more.

C. Extensor hallucis longus
• Innervated by deep peroneal nerve L5–S1; major S1 contribution.
• Common error: assuming big-toe extension isolates L5 but it often spares pure L5 lesions.

D. Peroneus longus
• Superficial peroneal nerve L5–S2; predominantly S1.
• Pitfall: equating foot eversion strength with L5 rather than S1 testing.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Myotonia congenita is a non-dystrophic channelopathy caused by mutations in CLCN1, the gene encoding the skeletal muscle chloride channel. Chloride influx normally stabilizes the resting membrane potential; reduced chloride conductance leads to membrane hyperexcitability manifesting as myotonia (delayed relaxation) and transient weakness. The “warm-up phenomenon”—improvement of stiffness and weakness with repeated contractions—is a hallmark of myotonia congenita. Thomsen disease follows autosomal dominant inheritance with vertical transmission (father to son), whereas Becker disease is autosomal recessive and often more severe. Recognizing inheritance patterns and exercise response differentiates subtypes and guides diagnosis in adolescence. (Word count: 109)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thomsen disease is due to heterozygous loss-of-function CLCN1 mutations leading to reduced chloride conductance and muscle hyperexcitability. The warm-up phenomenon reflects progressive inactivation of sodium channels and stabilization of the sarcolemmal membrane during repetitive activity. Autosomal dominant transmission explains an affected father and son. Electromyography (EMG) in Thomsen shows characteristic myotonic discharges (“dive-bomber” sound) without significant decrement on repetitive nerve stimulation. According to AANEM 2018 guidelines (level C evidence), genetic testing for CLCN1 confirms the diagnosis. A randomized, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial (Statland JM et al., Lancet Neurol. 2018; level A) demonstrated that mexiletine 200–400 mg/day significantly reduces stiffness and improves quality of life in non-dystrophic myotonia, supporting targeted therapy once diagnosis is established.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Becker disease
• Incorrect because Becker myotonia congenita is autosomal recessive (biallelic CLCN1 mutations) and typically does not transmit directly from an affected father to son.
• Misconception: Both Thomsen and Becker improve with exercise; inheritance pattern is the key differentiator.

C. Myotonic dystrophy
• Incorrect because myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DMPK CTG expansion) presents with multisystem features (cataracts, cardiac conduction defects, endocrine disturbances) and muscle weakness that does not improve with exercise.
• Misconception: Any myotonia equals dystrophy; in fact, DM1 myotonia is less pronounced, and warm-up phenomenon is absent.

D. Paramyotonia congenita
• Incorrect because paramyotonia congenita (SCN4A mutation) exhibits paradoxical myotonia worsened by exercise and cold, lacking the warm-up phenomenon.
• Misconception: All channelopathies present similarly; paramyotonia is exercise-aggravated, not relieved.

Clinical Pearls

- The warm-up phenomenon is tested often: instruct patients to repetitively grip and release—improvement confirms myotonia congenita.
• EMG shows high-frequency discharges (“dive-bomber” sound) that attenuate with repeated stimulation in myotonia congenita.
• Mexiletine (200–400 mg/day) is first-line therapy; monitor ECG and electrolytes for QT changes.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing paramyotonia congenita with myotonia congenita due to both having exercise-related stiffness—key is that paramyotonia worsens with exercise and cold, whereas myotonia congenita improves.
2. Assuming any familial myotonia is myotonic dystrophy; neglect multisystem signs (e.g., cataracts, endocrine issues) that distinguish dystrophy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Association of Neuromuscular & Electrodiagnostic Medicine (AANEM) 2018 guidelines: Recommend CLCN1 genetic testing to confirm non-dystrophic myotonia (level C evidence).
• Statland JM et al., Lancet Neurol. 2018: Phase 3 randomized, placebo-controlled trial demonstrating mexiletine 200–400 mg/day reduces stiffness severity and improves quality of life in non-dystrophic myotonia (level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Myotonia congenita involves the sarcolemmal chloride channels (ClC-1) in skeletal muscle fibers; ClC-1 channels account for ≥70% of resting chloride conductance in type I and II fibers, crucial for repolarization after action potentials.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CLCN1 loss-of-function mutations decrease chloride conductance, lowering the threshold for after-depolarizations and repetitive firing. Repeated contractions lead to sodium channel inactivation, reducing hyperexcitability (warm-up).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: exercise-induced stiffness, warm-up phenomenon, family history
2. Physical exam: percussion myotonia, grip-and-release test
3. EMG: characteristic myotonic discharges with attenuation on repeated stimulation
4. Genetic testing: sequence CLCN1 (Thomsen vs Becker)

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Mexiletine: Class Ib antiarrhythmic; blocks fast sodium channels, reducing repetitive discharges. Typical dosing 200 mg TID; adjust for renal/hepatic function; monitor ECG.
• Alternatives: lamotrigine, ranolazine in mexiletine-intolerant patients.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] CIDP is an acquired immune‐mediated disorder targeting Schwann cell myelin in peripheral nerves, leading to segmental demyelination. Demyelination results in slowed nerve conduction velocity, prolonged distal latencies, and conduction block. Clinically, large‐fiber involvement produces both sensory deficits (numbness, paresthesias) and motor weakness. The hallmark is a chronic course (progressive or relapsing–remitting) evolving over ≥8 weeks, distinguishing it from acute neuropathies. Recognition of symmetry and distribution (proximal + distal) guides differentiation from focal or purely sensory variants.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct: typical CIDP presents as a symmetrical sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting both proximal (e.g., shoulder girdle) and distal (e.g., foot dorsiflexors) muscles, over >8 weeks. The 2021 EAN/PNS guideline (Doneddu et al., European Journal of Neurology, 2021) grades this “typical CIDP” phenotype with Level A evidence. Electrophysiologically, demyelinating features (slowed conduction velocity <70% lower limit of normal, prolonged F-wave latencies, conduction block) confirm diagnosis. Treatment trials—ICE (2008)—demonstrated IVIG efficacy in typical CIDP (Level Ib evidence). This chronic, symmetrical involvement contrasts with acute GBS (onset <4 weeks), multifocal variants (MADSAM), and pure sensory forms.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Asymmetrical weakness with sensory loss
• Describes MADSAM (Lewis‐Sumner syndrome), a CIDP variant with multifocal, often distal nerve involvement.
• Misconception: assuming all demyelinating neuropathies must be stereotypically symmetrical.
• Differentiation: nerve conduction in MADSAM shows focal conduction block in individual nerves.

C. Rapidly progressive weakness over days
• Characteristic of Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS), an acute demyelinating polyneuropathy evolving over ≤4 weeks.
• Misconception: equating any demyelinating neuropathy with CIDP.
• Time course key: CIDP requires >8 weeks for chronic designation.

D. Isolated sensory symptoms
• Reflects pure sensory neuropathy (e.g., sensory CIDP variant or paraneoplastic sensory neuronopathy) but is not the classic sensorimotor CIDP phenotype.
• Misconception: underestimating the prevalence of motor involvement in CIDP.
• Motor deficits (weakness) distinguish typical CIDP from sensory-only forms.

2. Overlooking focal variants (MADSAM) when asymmetry is present—different prognosis and treatment response.

The “warm-up” phenomenon—improvement of stiffness with repeated use—is characteristic of myotonia congenita.
Inheritance patterns help distinguish subtypes: Thomsen disease is autosomal dominant (father‐son transmission), while Becker disease is autosomal recessive.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thomsen disease results from heterozygous CLCN1 mutations reducing sarcolemmal chloride conductance, leading to repetitive after‐potentials. Warm-up mitigates stiffness by enhancing Na⁺ channel inactivation. This AD form often presents in childhood with mild muscle hypertrophy and transient weakness that improves with activity. European Federation of Neurological Societies (2015) guidelines designate mexiletine as first-line therapy for symptom control (Level A evidence). A randomized trial (Statland et al., JAMA Neurology 2018) confirmed mexiletine’s efficacy in non-dystrophic myotonia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Becker disease
• Incorrect because Becker disease is the autosomal recessive form of myotonia congenita; onset is later, severity greater, and often lacks a true warm-up phenomenon seen in Thomsen disease.

C. Myotonic dystrophy
• Represents a CTG repeat expansion in DMPK (autosomal dominant) with multisystem features (cataracts, endocrine dysfunction) and progressive weakness; myotonia may paradoxically worsen with activity rather than improve.

D. Paramyotonia congenita
• Caused by SCN4A mutations; paradoxical myotonia worsens with cold and continued activity, without a sustained warm-up effect.

Clinical Pearls

• The warm-up phenomenon is pathognomonic for myotonia congenita.
• EMG shows high-frequency “dive-bomber” discharges in non-dystrophic myotonias.
• First-line treatment: mexiletine 150–300 mg TID, titrated to effect; monitor ECG for QTc prolongation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing paramyotonia congenita (worsening with exercise/cold) with myotonia congenita (improves with exercise).
2. Assuming all myotonias are dystrophic—myotonic dystrophy features systemic signs absent in congenital channelopathies.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Federation of Neurological Societies (2015): Consensus on non-dystrophic myotonias recommends genetic testing for CLCN1 and SCN4A mutations; mexiletine is Level A evidence for symptomatic relief.
• Statland JM et al., JAMA Neurology (2018): Randomized, placebo-controlled trial demonstrating mexiletine significantly reduces myotonia severity and improves patient-reported stiffness (Class I evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CLCN1 mutations reduce chloride conductance in sarcolemma → impaired repolarization → repetitive action potentials manifesting as myotonia. Warm-up improves Na⁺ channel inactivation, normalizing excitability.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical exam: confirm myotonia, warm-up phenomenon.
2. EMG: identify myotonic discharges.
3. Genetic testing: CLCN1 sequencing for Thomsen vs Becker; SCN4A if paramyotonia suspected.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Mexiletine: class IB antiarrhythmic stabilizes Na⁺ channels (start 150 mg TID, max 600 mg/day).
• Alternatives: lamotrigine, acetazolamide in refractory cases.
